Debiased Kernel Estimation of Spot Volatility in the Presence of Infinite Variation Jumps111All authors contributed equally to this work.

B. Cooper Boniece Department of Mathematics, Drexel University, PA 19104, USA (cooper.boniece@drexel.edu) Research supported in part by the NSF grant DMS-2413558.) JosÃ© E. Figueroa-LÃ³pez Department of Statistics and Data Science, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, MO 63130, USA (figueroa-lopez@wustl.edu). Research supported in part by the NSF grant: DMS-2413557. Tianwei Zhou Department of Statistics and Data Science, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, MO 63130, USA (tianweizhou@wustl.edu).
(Oct., 2025)
Abstract

Volatility estimation is a central problem in financial econometrics, but becomes particularly challenging when jump activity is high, a phenomenon observed empirically in highly traded financial securities. In this paper, we revisit the problem of spot volatility estimation for an ItÃ´ semimartingale with jumps of unbounded variation. We construct truncated kernel-based estimators and debiased variants that extend the efficiency frontier for spot volatility estimation in terms of the jump activity index YY, raising the previous bound Y<4/3Y<4/3 to Y<20/11Y<20/11, thereby covering nearly the entire admissible range Y<2Y<2. Compared with earlier work, our approach attains smaller asymptotic variances through the use of unbounded kernels, is simpler to implement, and has broader applicability under more flexible model assumptions. A comprehensive simulation study confirms that our procedures substantially outperform competing methods in finite samples.

1 Introduction

Spot volatility estimation is a central problem in financial econometrics, underpinning numerous critical applications ranging from short-horizon risk management to derivatives pricing and hedging. Formally, the core task is to estimate the coefficient ÏƒÏ„\sigma_{\tau} of the Brownian component of an ItÃ´ semimartingale XX at a fixed point of time Ï„\tau given high-frequency observations. For recent developments, we refer to [15, 7, 8, 19], as well as the monographs [10, 2] for in-depth treatments.

Widely observed empirically in high-frequency financial data, jumps are a salient feature of price dynamics, separate from fluctuations captured by diffusive movements in XX, and must be carefully accounted for when estimating volatility and related functionals of XX. When jump activity is high, however, standard estimation methods face inherent limitations, as estimation difficulty increases with the degree of jump activity of the underlying process. Three qualitatively distinct regimes can be distinguished: jumps of finite activity, infinite activity jumps of bounded variation, and infinite activity jumps of unbounded variation, the latter posing the greatest challenge, and the setting of the present work.

A fundamental approach to handling jumps is through truncation, introduced by [16]. Establishing jump-robustness for truncation-based methods classically amounts to two steps: suppose Î¸^nâ€‹(Î”1nâ€‹X,â€¦,Î”nnâ€‹X)\hat{\theta}_{n}(\Delta_{1}^{n}X,\dots,\Delta^{n}_{n}X) is an estimator of some functional Î¸\theta of the continuous component XcX^{c} of XX, where Î”inâ€‹U:=Utiâˆ’Utiâˆ’1\Delta_{i}^{n}U:=U_{t_{i}}-U_{t_{i-1}} denotes the itâ€‹hi^{th} increment of a generic process UU sampled at times 0<t0<â‹¯<tn=T0<t_{0}<\dots<t_{n}=T during a finite time period [0,T][0,T]. In the first step, one shows that the (infeasible) estimator Î¸^nCont:=Î¸^nâ€‹(Î”1nâ€‹Xc,â€¦,Î”nnâ€‹Xc)\hat{\theta}^{\text{Cont}}_{n}:=\hat{\theta}_{n}(\Delta_{1}^{n}X^{c},\dots,\Delta_{n}^{n}X^{c}) is consistent and satisfies a central limit theorem (CLT) with, say, rate rnr_{n}:

1rnâ€‹(Î¸^nâ€‹(Î”1nâ€‹Xc,â€¦,Î”nnâ€‹Xc)âˆ’Î¸)âŸ¶ğ’Ÿğ’©â€‹(0,VÎ¸).\frac{1}{r_{n}}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n}(\Delta_{1}^{n}X^{c},\dots,\Delta_{n}^{n}X^{c})-\theta\right)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}(0,V_{\theta}). (1)

Second, it is shown that, by choosing an appropriate threshold level vnâ†˜0v_{n}\searrow{}0, the truncated or thresholded version Î¸^nTâ€‹râ€‹uâ€‹nâ€‹c:=Î¸^nâ€‹(Î”1nâ€‹Xâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”1nâ€‹X|â‰¤vn},â€¦,Î”nâ€‹Xnâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”nnâ€‹X|â‰¤vn})\hat{\theta}^{Trunc}_{n}:=\hat{\theta}_{n}(\Delta_{1}^{n}X\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{1}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}},\dots,\Delta_{n}X^{n}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{n}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}}) is close enough to Î¸^Câ€‹oâ€‹nâ€‹t\hat{\theta}^{Cont} so that

1rnâ€‹(Î¸^nTruncâˆ’Î¸^nCont)=oPâ€‹(1).\frac{1}{r_{n}}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n}^{\text{Trunc}}-\hat{\theta}_{n}^{\text{Cont}}\right)=o_{P}(1). (2)

An emblematic example of this approach arises in the estimation of the integrated variance or volatility Iâ€‹V:=âˆ«0TÏƒs2â€‹ğ‘‘sIV:=\int_{0}^{T}\sigma^{2}_{s}ds, where one passes from the quantity

Iâ€‹V^Cont:=âˆ‘i=1n(Î”inâ€‹Xc)2,\widehat{IV}^{\text{Cont}}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\Delta_{i}^{n}X^{c})^{2}, (3)

to its truncated version

Iâ€‹V^Trunc:=âˆ‘i=1n(Î”inâ€‹X)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”inâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}.\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}{\bf 1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}}. (4)

By (essentially) employing the steps (1)-(2), it has been established that in the bounded variation case [17, 5], an efficient CLT (see, e.g., [11]) is possible:

nâ€‹(Iâ€‹V^Truncâˆ’Iâ€‹V)âŸ¶ğ’Ÿğ’©â€‹(0,2â€‹âˆ«0TÏƒs4â€‹ğ‘‘s).\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}}-IV\right)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}\left(0,2\int_{0}^{T}\sigma_{s}^{4}ds\right).

However, with unbounded-variation jumps, this approach alone falls short. It was proved by [5, 18] that nâ€‹(Iâ€‹V^Truncâˆ’Iâ€‹V)âŸ¶Pâˆ\sqrt{n}\big(\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}}-IV\big)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle P}}{{\longrightarrow}}\infty in the presence of an infinite variation symmetric stable LÃ©vy process, precisely because the bias of Iâ€‹V^Trunc\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}} â€“ and thus the difference (Iâ€‹V^Truncâˆ’Iâ€‹V^Cont)(\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}}-\widehat{IV}^{\text{Cont}}) â€“ vanishes too slowly.

Two methodological advances have since moved the field forward. The first is due to Jacod and Todorov [12, 13], who proposed an approach for integrated variance estimation based on the empirical characteristic function of the rescaled increments Î”inâ€‹X/Î”n\Delta_{i}^{n}X/\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}, where Î”n\Delta_{n} is the time span of the increment. After applying a suitable logarithmic transformation and debiasing procedure, this approach admits a CLT with optimal rate and variance, even in the case of unbounded variation jumps. However, with this method, full (rate and variance) efficiency is attainable only under specific conditions that require either the jump activity index YY to satisfy Y<3/2Y<3/2, or under additional restrictive jump symmetry assumptions. The second major advance was introduced more recently by [3], who showed that a debiasing method similar to [12] applied to the realized truncated variations (4) leads to a fully efficient estimator for any Yâ‰¤8/5Y\leq 8/5 without any symmetry conditions.

A natural next question is how these insights extend to the problem of spot volatility estimation. A standard and widely used approach to constructing spot volatility estimators is to apply kernel smoothing to an estimator of integrated variance,

Ïƒ^Ï„2=âˆ«Kbâ€‹(tâˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ‘‘Iâ€‹V^t,\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}=\int K_{b}(t-\tau)d\widehat{IV}_{t},

where Iâ€‹V^t\widehat{IV}_{t} denotes an estimator of Iâ€‹Vt=âˆ«0tÏƒs2â€‹ğ‘‘sIV_{t}=\int_{0}^{t}\sigma_{s}^{2}ds and Kbâ€‹(u):=Kâ€‹(u/b)/bK_{b}(u):=K(u/b)/b for a chosen kernel KK and a bandwidth b>0b>0. For instance, using the realized quadratic variation Iâ€‹V^t=âˆ‘i=1[nâ€‹t](Î”inâ€‹X)2\widehat{IV}_{t}=\sum_{i=1}^{[nt]}(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}, this reduces to

Ïƒ^Ï„2=âˆ‘i=1nKbâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”inâ€‹X)2,\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{b}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}, (5)

as proposed in [14, 6].

Spot volatility estimators differ markedly from their integrated volatility counterparts, with their local nature altering the efficiency picture in subtle but important ways: on the one hand, optimal convergence rates are of order nâˆ’1/4n^{-1/4} (compared with nâˆ’1/2n^{-1/2} in the integrated volatility case); on the other hand, kernel-based estimators enjoy a degree of built-in robustness against jumps, since â€œlargeâ€ jumps are relatively rare and are unlikely to fall in a narrow neighborhood of Ï„\tau where KbK_{b} places most of its mass. For instance, [10, Theorem 13.3.3] shows that in the case of uniform kernels (i.e., Kâ€‹(u)=ğŸ[0,1)â€‹(u)K(u)={\bf 1}_{[0,1)}(u) or Kâ€‹(u)=ğŸ(âˆ’1,0]â€‹(u)K(u)={\bf 1}_{(-1,0]}(u)) the estimator (5) admits a rate-optimal CLT even in the case of unbounded variation jumps, provided Y<4/3Y<4/3222The case of jumps of bounded variation corresponds to Y<1Y<1, while the jumps are of unbounded variation when Y>1Y>1.. However, high levels of jump activity can still degrade performance, and the rate becomes suboptimal for Yâ‰¥4/3Y\geq 4/3: in general, for any aâˆˆ(0,1/2]a\in(0,1/2] such that Y<2/(1+a)Y<2/(1+a), one can find a bandwidth bnb_{n} such that na/2â€‹(Ïƒ^Ï„2âˆ’ÏƒÏ„2)âŸ¶ğ’Ÿğ’©â€‹(0,VÏƒ)n^{a/2}(\hat{\sigma}_{\tau}^{2}-\sigma_{\tau}^{2})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}(0,V_{\sigma}), which yields a rate that is slower than nâˆ’2âˆ’Y2â€‹Yn^{-\frac{2-Y}{2Y}}. Thus, if, for instance, Yâ‰¤3/2Y\leq 3/2, the rate is slower than nâˆ’1/6n^{-1/6}. Surprisingly, following the two-step approach (1)-(2), even when thresholding is applied to (5), i.e.,

Ïƒ^Ï„2=âˆ‘i=1nKbâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”inâ€‹X)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”inâ€‹X|â‰¤vn},\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{b}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}{\bf 1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}}, (6)

there is no apparent asymptotic benefit: the optimal rate of nâˆ’1/4n^{-1/4} remains attainable only if Y<4/3Y<4/3, and the best possible rate when Yâ‰¥4/3Y\geq 4/3 remains bounded by nâˆ’2âˆ’Y2â€‹Yn^{-\frac{2-Y}{2Y}}, which is strictly slower.

Given these limitations, one may wonder if estimation performance can be improved by modifying the kernel KK. This question was addressed in [8], which extended the approach in [10] to two-sided kernels of unbounded support. Although the convergence rate remains unchanged, they established that the asymptotic variance can be substantially reduced. For example, using the kernel Kâ€‹(u)=.5â€‹eâˆ’|u|K(u)=.5e^{-|u|} leads to an asymptotic variance that is one-quarter of that obtained by a uniform kernel in the suboptimal rate regime (Yâ‰¥4/3)(Y\geq 4/3). Moreover, in the optimal rate regime (Y<4/3)(Y<4/3), this kernel was shown to be variance-optimal, highlighting the utility of unbounded kernels in general. However, we note that the results in both [10] and [8] are based on the two-step approach (1)-(2), which we depart from in the present work.

These findings motivate a fundamental question: can one develop methods that attain better rates â€“ possibly optimal â€“ beyond the boundary Y<4/3Y<4/3? A recent step in this direction was taken by [15], who developed a localized variant of the characteristic function approach of [12]. Assuming the infinite-variation jump component is of the form âˆ«0tÏ‡sâ€‹ğ‘‘Ls\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dL_{s}, where LL is a strictly YY-stable symmetric LÃ©vy process, and while restricting to the class of compactly-supported kernels that are continuously differentiable, they establish that their estimator satisfies

bnÎ”nâ€‹Ïƒ^Ï„2âˆ’ÏƒÏ„22â€‹ÏƒÏ„âŸ¶ğ’Ÿğ’©â€‹(0,âˆ«K2â€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘u),\sqrt{\frac{b_{n}}{\Delta_{n}}}\frac{\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}-\sigma^{2}_{\tau}}{\sqrt{2\sigma_{\tau}}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\cal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}\left(0,\int K^{2}(u)du\right), (7)

for any Yâ‰¤3/2Y\leq{}3/2, but with a suboptimal convergence rate (i.e., Î”nbnâ‰«nâˆ’1/4\sqrt{\frac{\Delta_{n}}{b_{n}}}\gg n^{-1/4}). By applying an additional debiasing step similar to that in [12], they further showed that associated tuning parameters can be chosen so that (7) holds for any Y<2Y<2, however, still with a suboptimal rate and under the jump symmetry condition described above. Consequently, the boundary Y<4/3Y<4/3 has long marked the limit of efficiency in spot volatility estimation, and the regime Yâ‰¥4/3Y\geq 4/3 has remained largely underexplored without symmetry assumptions.

In this work, we push this efficiency boundary substantially forward by introducing appropriately debiased versions of the estimator (6). First, by exploiting high-order expansions of the truncated moments of Î”iâ€‹X\Delta_{i}X, rather than relying on the coarser two-step framework (1)-(2), which does not explicitly account for higher-order bias, we show the estimator (6) actually achieves rate-optimality for any Yâ‰¤3/2Y\leq{}3/2 (namely, n1/4â€‹(Ïƒ^Ï„2âˆ’ÏƒÏ„2)âŸ¶ğ’Ÿğ’©â€‹(0,VÏƒ)n^{1/4}(\hat{\sigma}_{\tau}^{2}-\sigma_{\tau}^{2})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}(0,V_{\sigma})) under standard assumptions and without additional adjustment. Second, by introducing debiasing steps similar to those in [12, 3], we construct fully efficient estimators that cover the range 0<Y<20/110<Y<20/11. This extension is practically relevant, as empirical studies indicate that values of YY are typically between 1.51.5 and 1.81.8 for liquid stocks (see [3] for a brief supporting empirical analysis and further references). Our method stands in sharp contrast to the results in [15], offering rate-optimal estimators over a wider range of YY, broader applicability through more flexible model assumptions, reduced asymptotic variances enabled by the use of unbounded kernels, and simpler estimators that are easier to implement. To validate our results, we perform a comprehensive simulation study and find that our methods significantly outperform those of [15] in terms of both bias and variance over finite samples. Our findings further demonstrate that the advantages of kernels with unbounded support extend to the debiasing framework developed here, providing substantial improvements over widely-used uniform kernels, which are often the default choice in practice, especially in inference problems that require estimation of spot volatility as a preliminary step.

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the setting, assumptions, and preliminary results. Section 3 presents the main results and their proofs. Section 4 contains simulations assessing the performance of our estimators. Some additional technical proofs are collected in Appendix A.

2 Setting and background

Consider a 1-dimensional ItÃ´ semimartingale X=(Xt)tâˆˆâ„+X=\big(X_{t}\big)_{t\in\mathbb{R}_{+}} defined on a complete filtered probability space (Î©,â„±,(â„±)tâˆˆâ„+,â„™)\big(\Omega,\mathscr{F},(\mathscr{F})_{t\in\mathbb{R}_{+}},\mathbb{P}\big) that can be decomposed as

Xt=âˆ«0tbsâ€‹ğ‘‘s+âˆ«0tÏƒsâ€‹ğ‘‘Ws+âˆ«0tÏ‡sâˆ’â€‹ğ‘‘Js+âˆ«0tâˆ«Î´â€‹(s,z)â€‹ğ”­â€‹(dâ€‹s,dâ€‹z),tâˆˆ[0,âˆ),\displaystyle X_{t}=\int_{0}^{t}b_{s}ds+\int_{0}^{t}\sigma_{s}dW_{s}+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s^{-}}dJ_{s}+\int_{0}^{t}\int\delta(s,z)\mathfrak{p}(ds,dz),\;\;t\in[0,\infty), (8)

where W:=(Wt)tâˆˆâ„+W:=(W_{t})_{t\in\mathbb{R}_{+}} is a Wiener process, Ïƒ\sigma is an adapted cÃ dlÃ g process, J:=(Jt)tâˆˆâ„+J:=(J_{t})_{t\in\mathbb{R}_{+}} is an independent pure-jump LÃ©vy process with LÃ©vy triplet (b,0,v)(b,0,v), and ğ”­\mathfrak{p} is a Poisson random measure on â„+Ã—â„\mathbb{R}_{+}\times\mathbb{R} with an intensity ğ”®â€‹(dâ€‹s,dâ€‹z)=dâ€‹sâŠ—Î»â€‹(dâ€‹z)\mathfrak{q}(ds,dz)=ds\otimes\lambda(dz), such that the Î»\lambda is a Ïƒ\sigma-finite measure on â„\mathbb{R}, possibly dependent with JJ. The LÃ©vy measure vv is assumed to admit a density s:â„\{0}â†’â„+s:{\mathbb{R}\backslash\{0\}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+} of the form

sâ€‹(x):=dâ€‹vdâ€‹x:=(C+â€‹ğŸ(0,âˆ)â€‹(x)+Câˆ’â€‹ğŸ(âˆ’âˆ,0)â€‹(x))â€‹qâ€‹(x)â€‹|x|âˆ’1âˆ’Y.\displaystyle s(x):=\frac{dv}{dx}:=\big(C_{+}\mathbf{1}_{(0,\infty)}(x)+C_{-}\mathbf{1}_{(-\infty,0)}(x)\big)q(x)|x|^{-1-Y}. (9)

We have the following standing assumptions:

Assumption 1.
  1. 1.

    CÂ±>0C_{\pm}>0 and Yâˆˆ(0,2)âˆ–{1}Y\in(0,2)\setminus\{1\}.

  2. 2.

    q:â„\{0}â†’â„+q:{{\mathbb{R}\backslash\{0\}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}} is a bounded Borel-measurable function such that:

    1. (a)

      qâ€‹(x)â†’1q(x)\rightarrow 1, as xâ†’0x\rightarrow 0.

    2. (b)

      There exist aÂ±a_{\pm} such that

      âˆ«01|qâ€‹(x)âˆ’1âˆ’a+â€‹x|â€‹xâˆ’Yâˆ’1â€‹ğ‘‘x+âˆ«âˆ’10|qâ€‹(x)âˆ’1âˆ’aâˆ’â€‹x|â€‹|x|âˆ’Yâˆ’1â€‹ğ‘‘x<âˆ.\int_{0}^{1}\big|q(x)-1-a_{+}x\big|x^{-Y-1}dx+\int_{-1}^{0}\big|q(x)-1-a_{-}x\big||x|^{-Y-1}dx<\infty. (10)
  3. 3.

    The process Ï‡\chi is given as

    Ï‡t=Ï‡0+âˆ«0tbxÏ‡â€‹ğ‘‘s+âˆ«0tÎ£sÏ‡â€‹ğ‘‘Bs.\chi_{t}=\chi_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}b_{x}^{\chi}ds+\int_{0}^{t}\Sigma_{s}^{\chi}dB_{s}. (11)
  4. 4.

    The processes W,BW,B are standard Brownian motions with correlation dâ€‹âŸ¨W,BâŸ©t=Ïtâ€‹dâ€‹td\langle W,B\rangle_{t}=\rho_{t}dt for an adapted, locally bounded cÃ dlÃ g process {Ït}tâ‰¥0\{\rho_{t}\}_{t\geq 0}. W,BW,B are independent of (J,ğ”­)(J,\mathfrak{p}); JJ is independent of Ïƒ\sigma.

  5. 5.

    The processes Î£Ï‡\Sigma^{\chi}, bb, bÏ‡b^{\chi} are cÃ dlÃ g adapted, and Î´\delta is predictable. There exist a sequence {Ï„n}nâ‰¥1\{\tau_{n}\}_{n\geq 1} of stopping times increasing to infinity, nonnegative Î»â€‹(dâ€‹z)\lambda(dz)-integrable function HH and a positive sequence {Mn}nâ‰¥1\{M_{n}\}_{n\geq 1} such that

    tâ‰¤Ï„nâ‡’{|Ïƒt|+|bt|+|btÏ‡|+|Î£tÏ‡|â‰¤Mn,(|Î´â€‹(t,z)|âˆ§1)râ‰¤Mnâ€‹Hâ€‹(z),t\leq\tau_{n}\Rightarrow\begin{cases}|\sigma_{t}|+|b_{t}|+|b_{t}^{\chi}|+|\Sigma_{t}^{\chi}|\leq M_{n},\\ ({|\delta(t,z)|}\wedge 1)^{{r}}\leq M_{n}{H(z)},\end{cases}

    for some râˆˆ[0,1âˆ§Y){r}\in[0,1\wedge Y).

  6. 6.

    The spot variance process ct:=Ïƒt2c_{t}:=\sigma_{t}^{2} is assumed to follow the dynamics:

    ct=c0+âˆ«0tÎ¼~sâ€‹ğ‘‘s+âˆ«0tÏƒ~sâ€‹ğ‘‘Bs,\displaystyle c_{t}=c_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\tilde{\mu}_{s}ds+\int_{0}^{t}\tilde{\sigma}_{s}dB_{s}, (12)

    where B:=(Bt)tâ‰¥0B:=(B_{t})_{t\geq 0} is as in point 3 above. Here {Î¼~}tâ‰¥0\{\tilde{\mu}\}_{t\geq 0} and (Ïƒ~t)tâ‰¥0(\tilde{\sigma}_{t})_{t\geq 0} are adapted cÃ dlÃ g locally bounded processes.

Remark 1.

The conditions above are essentially the same as those in [3]. [15] considered a similar but more restrictive component of unbounded variation by taking JJ to be a symmetric strictly stable LÃ©vy process, while here we considered a type of tempered stable LÃ©vy process. The most technical (but still relatively mild) condition is that in (10), which is used to apply a density transformation or change of probability measure under which the process JJ becomes stable. We refer to [3] for further details.

We assume we have at our disposal nn evenly-spaced discrete observations XtiX_{t_{i}} during a fixed time interval [0,T][0,T]. For simplicity, we further assume T=1T=1 and, thus, ti=i/nt_{i}=i/n. Denote Î”n=1/n\Delta_{n}=1/n, â„±in:=â„±ti\mathcal{F}_{i}^{n}:=\mathcal{F}_{t_{i}}, and Î”inâ€‹A=Aiâ€‹Î”nâˆ’A(iâˆ’1)â€‹Î”n\Delta^{n}_{i}A=A_{i\Delta_{n}}-A_{(i-1)\Delta_{n}} for any process AA, where we often omit the superscript nn. Our estimation target is cÏ„=ÏƒÏ„2c_{\tau}=\sigma_{\tau}^{2} for a fixed time Ï„âˆˆ(0,T)\tau\in(0,T). We consider the spot volatility estimator

c^nâ€‹(mn,vn):=âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”inâ€‹X)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”inâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„),\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}):=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}, (13)

where KK is a kernel function, and mnm_{n} controls the bandwidth bn:=mnâ€‹Î”nb_{n}:=m_{n}\Delta_{n} such that mnâ†’âˆm_{n}\rightarrow\infty and mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0, and Kbâ€‹(x):=Kâ€‹(x/b)/bK_{b}(x):=K(x/b)/b. We assume the following conditions on KK, which are standard:

Assumption 2.

The kernel function K:â„â†’[0,âˆ)K:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow[0,\infty) is bounded and Lipschitz and piecewise C1C^{1} on (âˆ’âˆ,âˆ)(-\infty,\infty) such that âˆ«Kâ€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘x=1\int K(x)dx=1, âˆ«|Kâ€‹(x)â€‹x|â€‹ğ‘‘x<âˆ\int|K(x)x|dx<\infty, âˆ«|Kâ€²â€‹(x)|â€‹ğ‘‘x<âˆ\int|K^{\prime}(x)|dx<\infty, and Kâ€‹(y)â€‹y2â†’0K(y)y^{2}\rightarrow 0 as |y|â†’âˆ|y|\rightarrow\infty.

The estimator (13) without the denominator factor, truncation, or any debiasing was studied in [6] and [14] (see also additional references in the introduction). The denominator, motivated by the standard Nadarayan-Watson nonparametric regression estimator, and noted in passing in [14], serves a dual role: it provides edge correction in finite samples and simplifies several proofs, notably leading to more relaxed technical assumptions in the optimal bandwidth regime (see Remark 2 below). In contrast, when the denominator is omitted, our results remain valid, but stricter conditions on the bandwidth bn=mnâ€‹Î”nb_{n}=m_{n}\Delta_{n} and its relationship with YY are required; however, in the suboptimal rate regime (see Remark 2, case (ii), below), the denominator can be dispensed of entirely without any loss of generality. The truncated version in (13) was studied in [7] and [8], also without debiasing. Finally, Assumption 2 permits kernels of unbounded support, which, as discussed in the introduction, enables estimators that are more variance efficient in both the optimal and suboptimal convergence regimes.

Notation: Throughout, Anâ‰²BnA_{n}\lesssim B_{n} and anâ‰ªbna_{n}\ll b_{n} mean An=OPâ€‹(Bn)A_{n}=O_{P}(B_{n}) and an=oâ€‹(bn)a_{n}=o(b_{n}), respectively. For any process VV, when unambiguous we write Î”iâ€‹V\Delta_{i}V in place of Î”inâ€‹V\Delta_{i}^{n}V.

3 Main results

The following moment expansions play key roles in our analysis. The proofs are based on arguments in analogous results in [3] (see Lemmas 2, 3, 4 and 5 therein) and are given in Appendix A.1.5 for completeness.

Proposition 1.

Suppose that Yâˆˆ(0,2)âˆ–{1}Y\in(0,2)\setminus\{1\}. Let Î”n12âˆ’sâ‰ªvnâ‰ªÎ”n14âˆ’Y\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}-s}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}} for a fixed sâˆˆ(0,1/2)s\in(0,1/2). Then, the following statements hold:

  1. 1.

    For any integer pâ‰¥1p\geq 1, we have

    ğ”¼â€‹((Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}|â„±iâˆ’1)=(2â€‹pâˆ’1)!!â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np+Cp,iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y+oPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)+oPâ€‹(Î”np),\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)=(2{p}-1)!!\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2{p}}\Delta_{n}^{p}+C_{{p},i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2{p}-Y}+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2{p}-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{p}), (14)

    where Cp,i:=(C++Câˆ’)â€‹|Ï‡tiâˆ’1|Y2â€‹pâˆ’YC_{p,i}:=\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{t_{i-1}}|^{Y}}{2p-Y}.

  2. 2.

    Furthermore, if p=1p=1, the following high-order expansion holds:

    ğ”¼â€‹((Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}|â„±iâˆ’1)=Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹Î”n+C1,iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Y+D1,iâ€‹Î”n2â€‹vnâˆ’Y+OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)+oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4),\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2{}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)=\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Delta_{n}+C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}+D_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}), (15)

    where D1,i=(C++Câˆ’)â€‹(Y+1)â€‹(Y+2)2â€‹Yâ€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹|Ï‡tiâˆ’1|YD_{1,i}=\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})(Y+1)(Y+2)}{2Y}\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}|\chi_{t_{i-1}}|^{Y}. Additionally, for any Î¶>1\zeta>1, we have

    ğ”¼â€‹((Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹ğŸ{vn<|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤Î¶â€‹vn}|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2{}}\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}<|\Delta_{i}X|\leq\zeta v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big) =C1,iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(Î¶2âˆ’Yâˆ’1)â€‹vn2âˆ’Y+D1,iâ€‹Î”n2â€‹(Î¶âˆ’Yâˆ’1)â€‹vnâˆ’Y\displaystyle=C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}(\zeta^{2-Y}-1)v_{n}^{2-Y}+D_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}(\zeta^{-Y}-1)v_{n}^{-Y} (16)
    +OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)+oPâ€‹(Î”n34â€‹vn4âˆ’Y2).\displaystyle\quad+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}).
  3. 3.

    For any p>1p>1 (not necessarily an integer), we have

    ğ”¼â€‹(|Î”iâ€‹X|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}|â„±iâˆ’1)=OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)+OPâ€‹(Cp,tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y).\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big(|\Delta_{i}X|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2{p}}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(C_{{p},t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2{p}-Y}). (17)

To analyze the asymptotic behavior of the estimator c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) defined in Eq.Â (13), we consider the following decomposition:

c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)\displaystyle\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) =(c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)âˆ’Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))\displaystyle=\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\frac{\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}\right)
+(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))\displaystyle\quad+\left(\frac{\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}\right)
=:c^n,1(mn,vn)+c^n,2(mn).\displaystyle=:\hat{c}_{n,1}(m_{n},v_{n})+\hat{c}_{n,2}(m_{n}). (18)

Our next result is central to our analysis and underpins our main debiasing procedure. It establishes the joint asymptotic behavior of the terms in (3), accounting for appropriate bias terms, and provides the framework for separating qualitatively distinct asymptotic regimes for mnm_{n}. In addition, on its own, it yields feasible CLTs for c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) in certain settings that sharpen existing results in the literature (see Remark 2).

Theorem 1.

Suppose that Î”nÎ²â‰ªvnâ‰ªÎ”nÎ²â€²\Delta_{n}^{\beta}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\beta^{\prime}} with 14âˆ’Y<Î²â€²<Î²<12\frac{1}{4-Y}<\beta^{\prime}<\beta<\frac{1}{2}, logâ€‹(n)â‰ªmnâ‰ªÎ”nâˆ’4â€‹vn4+2â€‹Y\sqrt{\mathrm{log}(n)}\ll m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-4}v_{n}^{4+2Y}, and mn=Oâ€‹(Î”nâˆ’12)m_{n}=O(\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}). Let

Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) :=mnâ€‹(c^n,1â€‹(mn,vn)âˆ’Aâ€‹(vn,mn)),\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\hat{c}_{n,1}(m_{n},v_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})\Big),
Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}_{n}^{\prime}(m_{n}) :=1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(c^n,2â€‹(mn)âˆ’ÏƒÏ„2),\displaystyle:=\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\hat{c}_{n,2}(m_{n})-\sigma^{2}_{\tau}\Big),

where, using the notation in (15),

Aâ€‹(vn,mn):=âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹C1,iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’YÎ”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)+âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹D1,iâ€‹Î”n2â€‹vnâˆ’YÎ”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„).\displaystyle{A(v_{n},m_{n}):=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){C_{1,i}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}+\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){D_{1,i}}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}.} (19)

Then, under Assumptions 1 and 2, as nâ†’âˆn\rightarrow\infty,

(Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn),Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn))â†’sâ€‹t(Z1,Z2),\displaystyle(\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}),\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}))\xrightarrow{st}\mathcal{(}Z_{1},Z_{2}), (20)

where Z1âˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,2â€‹ÏƒÏ„4â€‹âˆ«K2â€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘x)Z_{1}\sim N\big(0,2\sigma_{\tau}^{4}\int K^{2}(x)dx\big) and Z2âˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,Ïƒ~Ï„2â€‹âˆ«L2â€‹(t)â€‹ğ‘‘t)Z_{2}\sim N(0,{\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}}\int L^{2}(t)dt) with Lâ€‹(t)=âˆ«tâˆKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸtâ‰¥0âˆ’âˆ«âˆ’âˆtKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸt<0L(t)=\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}, and Z1Z_{1} and Z2Z_{2} are independent.

Remark 2.

Taking mnâ†’âˆm_{n}\to\infty at different rates alters the balance of the errors appearing on the right-hand side of (20). Three distinct regimes can be distinguished: (i) mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’Î¸âˆˆ(0,âˆ)m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\theta\in(0,\infty), (ii) mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’0m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to 0, and (iii) mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’âˆm_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\infty, which we remark on below.

Case (i): mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’Î¸âˆˆ(0,âˆ)m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\theta\in(0,\infty). In this regime, the orders of mn\sqrt{m_{n}} and 1/mnâ€‹Î”n1/\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}} match, in which case Theorem 1 gives

Î”nâˆ’1/4â€‹(c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)âˆ’Aâ€‹(vn,mn)âˆ’ÏƒÏ„2)â†’sâ€‹tÎ¸âˆ’1/2â€‹Z1+Î¸1/2â€‹Z2,\Delta_{n}^{-1/4}\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2}\right)\xrightarrow{st}\theta^{-1/2}Z_{1}+\theta^{1/2}Z_{2}, (21)

or, equivalently,

mnâ€‹(c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)âˆ’Aâ€‹(vn,mn)âˆ’ÏƒÏ„2)â†’sâ€‹tZ1+Î¸â€‹Z2.\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2}\right)\xrightarrow{st}Z_{1}+\theta Z_{2}. (22)

Note that the bias term Aâ€‹(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) is OPâ€‹(vn2âˆ’Y)O_{P}(v_{n}^{2-Y}). Thus, if mnâ€‹vn2âˆ’Yâ‰ª1\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}\ll 1, then (21) and (22) remain true even with the term Aâ€‹(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) omitted, in which case we obtain a valid feasible CLT for the estimation error c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)âˆ’ÏƒÏ„2\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2} with convergence rate Î”n1/4\Delta_{n}^{1/4} (which is optimal). While the condition mnâ€‹vn2âˆ’Yâ‰ª1\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}\ll 1 can be met in principle by taking small enough vnv_{n}, Theorem 1 additionally requires vnâ‰«Î”n1/2v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{1/2}, and thus implicitly Î”nâˆ’1/4â€‹Î”n(2âˆ’Y)/2â‰ª1\Delta_{n}^{-1/4}\Delta_{n}^{(2-Y)/2}\ll 1, which can happen only if Y<3/2Y<3/2. Nevertheless, this result significantly improves upon [8] (and also [10]), where a rate-optimal CLT is shown to be valid only when Y<4/3Y<4/3. Theorem 1 also yields stronger results than the characteristic function approach taken in [15], in which a similar CLT is is shown to be valid, under substantially more restrictive model assumptions333For instance, they assume that the process JJ in (8) is a symmetric stable LÃ©vy process, for Y<3/2Y<3/2 at a convergent rate strictly slower than Î”n1/4\Delta_{n}^{1/4} (due to an assumption that mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’0m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to{}0).

Further, under case (i), the conditions on vnv_{n} take the form Î”nÎ²âˆ¨Î”n74â€‹Y+8â‰ªvnâ‰ªÎ”nÎ²â€²\Delta_{n}^{\beta}\vee\Delta_{n}^{\frac{7}{4Y+8}}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\beta^{\prime}} (14âˆ’Y<Î²â€²<Î²<12\frac{1}{4-Y}<\beta^{\prime}<\beta<\frac{1}{2}), which can hold only if 74â€‹Y+8>14âˆ’Y\frac{7}{4Y+8}>\frac{1}{4-Y}, which requires Y<2011Y<\frac{20}{11}. Thus, this rate-optimal case (i) covers nearly the entire admissible range of YY observed in applications, and ultimately underpins our feasible efficient CLT in this range (Theorem 3).

Case (ii): mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’0m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to 0. This regime corresponds to setting Î¸=0\theta=0 in (22). Indeed,

mnâ€‹(c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)âˆ’Aâ€‹(vn,mn)âˆ’ÏƒÏ„2)=Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn)+mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn,vn),\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2}\right)=\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})+m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}), (23)

and, from (20), the first term above converges to Z1Z_{1}, while the second is oPâ€‹(1)o_{P}(1). In this case, the attained convergence rate, 1/mn1/\sqrt{m_{n}}, is suboptimal, i.e., slower than the Î”1/4\Delta^{1/4} rate achieved when Î¸âˆˆ(0,âˆ)\theta\in(0,\infty). However, this asymptotic regime has the practical advantage that any eventual estimation of the volatility-of-volatiltity Ïƒ~Ï„2\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}^{2} is not needed when constructing confidence intervals, since Z2Z_{2} is absent from the limit. If we also require mnâ€‹vn2âˆ’Yâ‰ª1\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}\ll 1, then the bias Aâ€‹(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) can be omitted in (23) leading to a feasible CLT for c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) centered at ÏƒÏ„2\sigma_{\tau}^{2}. Under this constraint, the condition vnâ‰«Î”n12v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}} and the asymptotic condition of case (ii) together imply that the convergence rate mnâˆ’1/2m_{n}^{-1/2} must be strictly slower than Î”n14âˆ§2âˆ’Y2\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4}\wedge\frac{2-Y}{2}}, yielding a convergence rate that can be taken arbitrarily close to Î”n1/4\Delta_{n}^{1/4} when Y<3/2Y<3/2 but deteriorates as YY increases to 22.

Case (iii): mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’âˆm_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\infty. Though technically excluded from our hypotheses, our results can also cover the regime mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’âˆm_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\infty, but at the expense of an upper bound of Y<8/5Y<8/5 in the jump activity index. In this setting, the attained convergence rate is mnâ€‹Î”n\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}, which is not as fast as the analogous rates when Î¸âˆˆ[0,âˆ)\theta\in[0,\infty).

Remark 3.

Beyond finite-sample edge correction, the denominator in (13) (which converges to 1) relaxes the technical conditions required for our results; without it, additional restrictions on YY and mnm_{n} are necessary. Specifically, define c~nâ€‹(mn,vn):=âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}{\tilde{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}, and let Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn)\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}), Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn)\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}), and Aâ€‹(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) denote the corresponding analogs without the denominator. Then the limit (20) still holds under the hypotheses of TheoremÂ 1, provided also that mnâ‰«Î”nâˆ’1/3m_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{-1/3}. Under this additional condition on mnm_{n}, (22) remains valid for Y<20/11Y<20/11 when mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’Î¸âˆˆ(0,âˆ)m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\theta\in(0,\infty). However, a much more substantive difference arises when mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’0m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to 0: if we also impose mnâ€‹vn2âˆ’Yâ‰ª1\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}\ll 1 to obtain a feasible CLT (as discussed in RemarkÂ 2), the constraint becomes Î”nâˆ’1/3â‰ªmnâ‰ªvn2â€‹(Yâˆ’2)â‰ªÎ”nYâˆ’2\Delta_{n}^{-1/3}\ll m_{n}\ll v_{n}^{2(Y-2)}\ll\Delta_{n}^{Y-2}, which can only be satisfied if Y<5/3Y<5/3, illustrating the benefit of including the denominator factor in (13).

Proof of Theorem 1.

Denote

Yi\displaystyle Y_{i} :=mnâ€‹Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn},\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}},
Yiâ€²\displaystyle Y^{\prime}_{i} :=Î”nmnâ€‹Î”nÃ—{0,ifÂ â€‹i=1,âˆ’(âˆ‘l=1iâˆ’1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))â€‹Î”iâ€‹B,ifÂ â€‹2â‰¤iâ‰¤âŒˆÏ„/Î”nâŒ‰,(âˆ‘l=inKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))â€‹Î”iâ€‹B,ifÂ â€‹âŒˆÏ„/Î”nâŒ‰<iâ‰¤n.\displaystyle:=\frac{\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\times\left\{\begin{aligned} &0,\;&\text{if }i=1,\\ -&\Big(\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\Delta_{i}B,\;&\text{if }2\leq i\leq\lceil\tau/\Delta_{n}\rceil,\\ &\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\Delta_{i}B,\;&\text{if }\lceil\tau/\Delta_{n}\rceil<i\leq n.\end{aligned}\right.

Consider the following decompositions:

Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) =(âˆ‘i=1nYiÎ”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yi|â„±iâˆ’1)Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))\displaystyle=\Big(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\Big)
+(âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yi|â„±iâˆ’1)Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)âˆ’mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12âˆ’mnâ€‹Aâ€‹(vn,mn))\displaystyle\qquad+\Big(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}-\sqrt{m_{n}}A(v_{n},m_{n})\Big)
=:T1+T2,\displaystyle=:T_{1}+T_{2}, (24)

and

Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}) =Ïƒ~Ï„â€‹âˆ‘i=1nYiâ€²Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)+(Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn)âˆ’Ïƒ~Ï„â€‹âˆ‘i=1nYiâ€²Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))\displaystyle=\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}+\Big({\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n})}-\frac{\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\Big)
=Ïƒ~Ï„â€‹âˆ‘i=1nYiâ€²Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)\displaystyle=\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}
+(Î”nmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12âˆ’ÏƒÏ„2)Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)âˆ’Ïƒ~Ï„â€‹âˆ‘i=1nYiâ€²Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))\displaystyle\quad+\Big(\frac{\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}-\sigma^{2}_{\tau})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\Big)
=:T3+T4.\displaystyle=:T_{3}+T_{4}. (25)

We now proceed to show (T1,T3)â†’sâ€‹t(Z1,Ïƒ~Ï„â€‹Z2)(T_{1},T_{3})\xrightarrow{st}(Z_{1},\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}Z_{2}) by verifying the conditions of Theorem 2.2.15 in [10], and in addition that T2T_{2} and T4T_{4} are asymptotically negligible.

a) We start with T3T_{3}. Clearly, ğ”¼â€‹(Yiâ€²|â„±iâˆ’1)=0\mathbb{E}(Y^{\prime}_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})=0 and, using the moment formula for Gaussian distributions and Lemma 3.1 in [9], we have

âˆ‘i=1nVarâ€‹(Yiâ€²|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\mathrm{Var}(Y^{\prime}_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})} =Î”n2mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1n((âˆ’âˆ‘l=1iâˆ’1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))2â€‹Î”nâ€‹ğŸÏ„â‰¥ti+(âˆ‘l=inKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))2â€‹Î”nâ€‹ğŸÏ„<ti)\displaystyle=\frac{\Delta_{n}^{2}}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Big(-\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)^{2}\Delta_{n}\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)^{2}\Delta_{n}\mathbf{1}_{\tau<t_{i}}\right)
=1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ«01(âˆ«v1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(sâˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ‘‘sâ€‹ğŸÏ„â‰¥vâˆ’âˆ«0vKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(sâˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ‘‘sâ€‹ğŸÏ„<v)2â€‹ğ‘‘v+oPâ€‹(1)\displaystyle\quad=\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\int_{0}^{1}\Big(\int_{{v}}^{1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}({s}-\tau)ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq{v}}-\int^{{v}}_{0}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}({s}-\tau)ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau<{v}}\Big)^{2}dv+o_{P}(1)
â†’ğ‘ƒâˆ«(âˆ«tâˆKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸtâ‰¥0âˆ’âˆ«âˆ’âˆtKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸt<0)2â€‹ğ‘‘t,\displaystyle\quad\xrightarrow{P}\int\Big(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}\Big)^{2}dt,

and

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yâ€²i4|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}({Y^{\prime}}_{i}^{4}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =3â€‹Î”n4mn2â€‹Î”n2â€‹âˆ‘i=1n((âˆ‘l=1iâˆ’1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))4â€‹Î”n2â€‹ğŸÏ„â‰¥ti+(âˆ‘l=inKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))4â€‹Î”n2â€‹ğŸÏ„<i)\displaystyle=\frac{3\Delta_{n}^{4}}{m_{n}^{2}\Delta_{n}^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Big(\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)^{4}\Delta_{n}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)^{4}\Delta_{n}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\tau<i}\right)
=3mnâ€‹âˆ«(âˆ«tâˆKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸtâ‰¥0âˆ’âˆ«âˆ’âˆtKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸt<0)4â€‹ğ‘‘t+oPâ€‹(1)â†’ğ‘ƒ0.\displaystyle\quad=\frac{3}{m_{n}}\int\left(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}\right)^{4}dt+o_{P}(1)\xrightarrow{P}0.

On the other hand, by Assumption 2 and Lemma 3.1 in [9], with fâ‰¡1f\equiv 1 and m=1m=1 therein, we have

Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)âˆ’1=Oâ€‹(mnâˆ’1),\displaystyle\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)-1={O(m_{n}^{-1})}, (26)

which vanishes as nâ†’âˆn\rightarrow\infty. Therefore,

âˆ‘i=1nVarâ€‹(Yiâ€²|â„±iâˆ’1)(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))2â†’ğ‘ƒâˆ«(âˆ«tâˆKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸtâ‰¥0âˆ’âˆ«âˆ’âˆtKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸt<0)2â€‹ğ‘‘t,\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\mathrm{Var}(Y^{\prime}_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}}{{\big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)\big)^{2}}}\xrightarrow{P}\int\Big(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}\Big)^{2}dt,
andÂ â€‹âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yâ€²i4|â„±iâˆ’1)(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))4â†’0.\displaystyle\text{and }\;\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}({Y^{\prime}}_{i}^{4}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)\big)^{4}}\rightarrow 0.

To conclude T3â†’sâ€‹tÏƒ~Ï„â€‹Z2T_{3}\xrightarrow{st}\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}Z_{2}, from Theorem 2.2.15 in [10] it suffices to show the following technical condition:

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Yiâ€²â€‹Î”iâ€‹M)â†’0,\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(Y^{\prime}_{i}\Delta_{i}M\big)\rightarrow 0, (27)

where ğ”¼iâˆ’1(â‹…)=ğ”¼(â‹…|â„±iâˆ’1)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}(\cdot|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) and MM is either WW or BB or is in the set ğ’©\mathcal{N} containing all bounded martingales orthogonal to WW and BB. When M=BM=B, we have

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yiâ€²â€‹Î”iâ€‹B|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y^{\prime}_{i}\Delta_{i}B|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =Î”nmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1n(âˆ’(âˆ‘l=1iâˆ’1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))â€‹Î”nâ€‹ğŸÏ„â‰¥ti+(âˆ‘l=inKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))â€‹Î”nâ€‹ğŸÏ„<ti)\displaystyle=\frac{\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(-\Big(\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\Delta_{n}\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\Delta_{n}\mathbf{1}_{\tau<{t_{i}}}\right)
=1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ«01(âˆ«v1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(sâˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ‘‘sâ€‹ğŸÏ„â‰¥vâˆ’âˆ«0vKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(sâˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ‘‘sâ€‹ğŸÏ„<v)â€‹ğ‘‘v+oâ€‹(1)\displaystyle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\int_{0}^{1}\Big(\int_{{v}}^{1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}({s}-{\tau})ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq{v}}-\int^{{v}}_{0}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(s-{\tau})ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau<{v}}\Big)d{v}+o(1)
=mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ«(âˆ«tâˆKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸtâ‰¥0âˆ’âˆ«âˆ’âˆtKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸt<0)â€‹ğ‘‘t+oâ€‹(1)â†’ğ‘ƒ0.\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\int\Big(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}\Big)d{t}+o(1)\xrightarrow{P}0.

When Mâˆˆğ’©M\in\mathcal{N} or M=WM=W, since ğ”¼â€‹(Î”iâ€‹Bâ€‹Î”iâ€‹W|â„±iâˆ’1)=OPâ€‹(Î”n)\mathbb{E}(\Delta_{i}B\Delta_{i}W|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}), similar to the case with M=BM=B, we obtain

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yiâ€²â€‹Î”iâ€‹M|â„±iâˆ’1)â‰²1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ«(âˆ«tâˆKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸÏ„â‰¥0âˆ’âˆ«âˆ’âˆtKâ€‹(u)â€‹ğ‘‘uâ€‹ğŸÏ„<0)â€‹ğ‘‘tâ†’0.\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}\big(Y^{\prime}_{i}\Delta_{i}M|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)\lesssim\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\int\Big(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{\tau<0}\Big)dt\rightarrow 0.

b) Next, we work with the term T4T_{4} of (3). Let iâ€²âˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}i^{\prime}\in\{1,\dots,n\} be such that Ï„âˆˆ(tiâ€²âˆ’1,tiâ€²]\tau\in(t_{i^{\prime}-1},t_{i^{\prime}}]. Notice that

âˆ‘i=1nYiâ€²\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime} =âˆ’âˆ‘l=1iâ€²âˆ’1(âˆ‘i=l+1iâ€²Î”iâ€‹B)â€‹Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)+âˆ‘l=iâ€²+1n(âˆ‘i=iâ€²+1lÎ”iâ€‹B)â€‹Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)\displaystyle=-\sum_{l=1}^{i^{\prime}-1}\big(\sum_{i=l+1}^{i^{\prime}}\Delta_{i}B\big)K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)+\sum_{l=i^{\prime}+1}^{n}\big(\sum_{i=i^{\prime}+1}^{l}\Delta_{i}B\big)K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau) (28)
=âˆ‘l=1iâ€²âˆ’1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Btlâˆ’Btiâ€²)+âˆ‘l=iâ€²+1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Btlâˆ’Btiâ€²).\displaystyle=\sum_{l=1}^{i^{\prime}-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)(B_{t_{l}}-B_{t_{i^{\prime}}})+\sum_{l=i^{\prime}+1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)(B_{t_{l}}-B_{t_{i^{\prime}}}). (29)

In light of (26), we can then write

|T4|\displaystyle|T_{4}| â‰²|1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(âˆ«Ï„tiâˆ’1(Ïƒ~sâˆ’Ïƒ~Ï„)â€‹ğ‘‘Bs+âˆ«Ï„tiâˆ’1Î¼~sâ€‹ğ‘‘s))|\displaystyle\lesssim\Big|\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}(\tilde{\sigma}_{s}-\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau})dB_{s}+\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}\tilde{\mu}_{s}ds\big)\Big)\Big|
+|1mnâ€‹Î”nÎ”nâˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”n(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)(âˆ«tiâˆ’1tiÏƒ~Ï„dBs+âˆ«Ï„tiâ€²Ïƒ~Ï„dBs)|=:|T4,1|+|T4,2|.\displaystyle\quad+\Big|\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\Big(\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}dB_{s}+\int_{\tau}^{t_{i^{\prime}}}\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}dB_{s}\Big)\Big|=:|T_{4,1}|+|T_{4,2}|. (30)

Since |Btiâ€²âˆ’BÏ„|=OPâ€‹(Î”n1/2)|B_{t_{i^{\prime}}}-B_{\tau}|=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{1/2}) and supi|Btiâˆ’Btiâˆ’1|=OPâ€‹(Î”n1/2â€‹logâ€‹(n)1/2)\sup_{i}|B_{t_{i}}-B_{t_{i-1}}|=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\mathrm{log}(n)^{1/2}), the second term T4,2T_{4,2} has order OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹logâ€‹(n)mnâ€‹Î”n)O_{P}(\frac{\sqrt{\Delta_{n}\mathrm{log}(n)}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}) and vanishes given that mnâ‰«logâ€‹(n)m_{n}\gg\sqrt{\mathrm{log}(n)} as nâ†’âˆn\rightarrow\infty. We just need to worry about the first term. Let

Î·i:=âˆ«Ï„tiâˆ’1(Ïƒ~Ï„âˆ’Ïƒ~s)â€‹ğ‘‘Bs+âˆ«Ï„tiâˆ’1Î¼~sâ€‹ğ‘‘s,andÏâ€‹(i):=1tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„â€‹ğ”¼â€‹(âˆ«Ï„tiâˆ’1|Ïƒ~sâˆ’Ïƒ~Ï„|2â€‹ğ‘‘s).\eta_{i}:=\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}(\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}-\tilde{\sigma}_{s})dB_{s}+\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}\tilde{\mu}_{s}ds,\quad\text{and}\quad\quad\rho(i):=\frac{1}{t_{i-1}-\tau}\mathbb{E}\Big(\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}|\tilde{\sigma}_{s}-\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}|^{2}ds\Big).

Note that, following the same argument as in the proof of (13.3.37) for j=6j=6 in [10] (see also the proof of (A.6) for l=4l=4 in [8]), and using that Ïƒ~\tilde{\sigma} is cÃ dlÃ g and bounded, for any positive sequence Nnâ†’âˆN_{n}\rightarrow\infty with mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹Nnâ†’0m_{n}\Delta_{n}N_{n}\rightarrow 0 as nâ†’âˆn\rightarrow\infty, it holds that

ğ”¼â€‹(Î·i2â€‹1iâˆˆâ„n)â‰¤câ€‹|tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„|â€‹Ïâ€‹(i)andsupiâˆˆâ„nÏâ€‹(i)â†’0,\mathbb{E}(\eta_{i}^{2}1_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}})\leq c|t_{i-1}-\tau|\rho(i)\quad\text{and}\quad\sup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\rho(i)\rightarrow 0,

where â„n:={iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}:tiâˆˆ(Ï„âˆ’Nâ€‹mnâ€‹Î”n,Ï„+Nâ€‹mnâ€‹Î”n)}\mathcal{I}_{n}:=\{i\in\{1,\dots,n\}:t_{i}\in(\tau-Nm_{n}\Delta_{n},\tau+Nm_{n}\Delta_{n})\}. Additionally, using the ItÃ´ isometry and boundedness of Ïƒ~\tilde{\sigma} and Î¼~\tilde{\mu}, it is easily seen that ğ”¼â€‹Î·i2â‰²|Ï„âˆ’ti|\mathbb{E}\eta_{i}^{2}\lesssim|\tau-t_{i}| for any ii. Thus,

ğ”¼â€‹|T4,1|\displaystyle\mathbb{E}|T_{4,1}| â‰²1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(ğŸiâˆˆâ„n+ğŸiâˆ‰â„n)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹Î·i2)\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){\left(\mathbf{1}_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}+\mathbf{1}_{i\notin\mathcal{I}_{n}}\right)}\sqrt{\mathbb{E}\eta_{i}^{2}}\Big)
â‰²1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1n1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹ğŸiâˆˆâ„nâ€‹|tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„|â€‹Ïi)\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\mathbf{1}_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\sqrt{|t_{i-1}-\tau|\rho_{i}}\Big)
+1mnâ€‹Î”n(Î”nâˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”n(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))ğŸiâˆ‰â„n|tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„|)\displaystyle\quad+\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau))\mathbf{1}_{i\notin\mathcal{I}_{n}}\sqrt{|t_{i-1}-\tau|}\Big)
â‰²mnâ€‹Î”nmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹mnâ€‹Î”nNnNnâ€‹mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹supiâˆˆâ„nÏi+âˆ«|u|>NK(u)|u|du).\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}m_{n}\Delta_{n}}N_{n}\sqrt{N_{n}m_{n}\Delta_{n}\sup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\rho_{i}}+\int_{|u|>N}K(u)\sqrt{|u|}du\Big).

Then, we see that T4=oPâ€‹(1)T_{4}=o_{P}(1) by taking Nnâ†’âˆN_{n}\to\infty slow enough such that Nn3/2â€‹supiâˆˆâ„nÏiâ†’0N_{n}^{3/2}\sup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\rho_{i}\rightarrow 0 (such an NnN_{n} is possible since as NnN_{n} diverges more slowly, the quantity supiâˆˆâ„nÏi\sup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\rho_{i} vanishes at a faster rate). Now, we conclude

1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn)â†’Nâ€‹(0,Ïƒ~Ï„2â€‹L2â€‹(t)).\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n})\rightarrow N\big(0,\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}^{2}L^{2}(t)\big).

c) We now proceed to consider T1T_{1} and T2T_{2} of Eq.Â (3). First, by Proposition 1, for any p>2p>2, we can write

ğ”¼â€‹(Yi|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =mnâ€‹Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹Î”n+C1,iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Y+D1,iâ€‹Î”n2â€‹vnâˆ’Y+OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)+oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4)),\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Delta_{n}+C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}+D_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4})\big),
ğ”¼â€‹(Yip|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}^{p}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) â‰²mnp/2â€‹Kmnâ€‹Î”npâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”npâ€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹p+Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y),\displaystyle\lesssim m_{n}^{p/2}K^{p}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(\Delta_{n}^{p}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}\big),
Varâ€‹(Yi|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle\mathrm{Var}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =mnâ€‹Kmnâ€‹Î”n2â€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(2â€‹Î”n2â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’14+OPâ€‹(Î”n2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y)+Oâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn4âˆ’Y))\displaystyle=m_{n}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(2\Delta_{n}^{2}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{4}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-Y})+O(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})\big)
=mnâ€‹Kmnâ€‹Î”n2â€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(2â€‹Î”n2â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’14+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn4âˆ’Y)).\displaystyle=m_{n}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(2\Delta_{n}^{2}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{4}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})\big).

Then,

s1â€‹n2:=âˆ‘i=1nVarâ€‹(Yi|â„±iâˆ’1)=mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”n2â€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(2â€‹Î”n2â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’14+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn4âˆ’Y)).s_{1n}^{2}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathrm{Var}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})=m_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(2\Delta_{n}^{2}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{4}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})\big).

Given vnâ‰ªÎ”n14âˆ’Yv_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}} and (26), we obtain

s1â€‹n2(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))2â†’2â€‹ÏƒÏ„4â€‹âˆ«K2â€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘x.\displaystyle\frac{s_{1n}^{2}}{(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau))^{2}}\rightarrow 2\sigma^{4}_{\tau}\int K^{2}(x)dx.

Moreover, we have

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yip|â„±iâˆ’1)â‰²1mnp/2âˆ’1â€‹Î”npâˆ’1â€‹âˆ«Kpâ€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘xâ€‹(ÏƒÏ„2â€‹pâ€‹Î”npâˆ’1+OPâ€‹(vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)).\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}^{p}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})\lesssim\frac{1}{m_{n}^{p/2-1}\Delta_{n}^{p-1}}\int K^{p}(x)dx(\sigma^{2p}_{\tau}\Delta_{n}^{p-1}+O_{P}(v_{n}^{2p-Y})).

If we rewrite p=(2â€‹â„“+1)/â„“p=(2\ell+1)/\ell for some â„“>0{\ell}>0, the right-hand side of the above inequality vanishes if and only if

mnâˆ’12â€‹â„“â€‹Î”nâˆ’1âˆ’1â„“â€‹vn4â€‹â„“+2â„“âˆ’Y=((Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vn4âˆ’Y)â„“â€‹(mnâˆ’12â€‹Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vn2))1â„“=Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vn4âˆ’Yâ€‹(mnâˆ’12â€‹Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vn2)1â„“â†’0.\displaystyle m_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2\ell}}\Delta_{n}^{-1-\frac{1}{\ell}}v_{n}^{\frac{4\ell+2}{\ell}-Y}=\Big((\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y})^{\ell}(m_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{2})\Big)^{\frac{1}{\ell}}=\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y}\Big(m_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{2}\Big)^{\frac{1}{\ell}}\rightarrow 0.

Since Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vn4âˆ’Yâ‰ªÎ”nÎ²â€²â€‹(4âˆ’Y)âˆ’1â‰ªÎ”ns\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\beta^{\prime}(4-Y)-1}\ll\Delta_{n}^{s} for small enough s>0s>0, the above vanishes by picking â„“\ell large enough. In light of (26), we also have âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yip|â„±iâˆ’1)(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))pâ†’0\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}^{p}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau))^{p}}\rightarrow 0 as nâ†’âˆn\rightarrow\infty for such an â„“\ell. To show T2=oPâ€‹(1)T_{2}=o_{P}(1), recall mn=Oâ€‹(Î”nâˆ’12)m_{n}=O(\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}) and, thus, by Proposition 1 and (26),

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yi|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Î”nâ€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12+mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹C1,iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Y\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\Delta_{n}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}+\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}
+mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹D1,iâ€‹Î”n2â€‹vnâˆ’Y+OPâ€‹(mnâ€‹Î”n2â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)+oPâ€‹(1).\displaystyle+\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)D_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}+O_{P}(\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(1). (31)

Hence,

T2\displaystyle T_{2} =âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Yi|â„±iâˆ’1)Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)âˆ’mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12âˆ’mnâ€‹Aâ€‹(vn,mn)\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}-\sqrt{m_{n}}A(v_{n},m_{n})
=OPâ€‹(mnâ€‹Î”n2â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y),\displaystyle=O_{P}(\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-2-Y}),

which vanishes due to the condition mnâ‰ªÎ”nâˆ’4â€‹vn4+2â€‹Ym_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-4}v_{n}^{4+2Y}. To obtain T1â†’sâ€‹tZ1T_{1}\xrightarrow{st}Z_{1}, by Theorem 2.2.15 in [10], it suffices to check the condition:

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Yiâ€‹Î”iâ€‹M)â†’0,\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(Y_{i}\Delta_{i}M\big)\rightarrow 0, (32)

where MM is either WW or BB or is in the set ğ’©\mathcal{N} containing all bounded martingales orthogonal to WW and BB. The proof of (32) is technical and is deferred to Appendix A.2. This concludes the proof for Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn)â†’sâ€‹tZ1\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\xrightarrow{st}Z_{1}.

d) To establish the joint convergence (20) and the asymptotic independence of T1,T2T_{1},T_{2}, it is sufficient to show that

supi|ğ”¼((Î”iX)2ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}Î”iB|â„±iâˆ’1)|=oP(Î”n3/2),\displaystyle\sup_{i}\Big|\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)\Big|=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}), (33)

which is shown in Appendix A.2. Indeed, from (33) we obtain:

âˆ‘i=1n|ğ”¼(YiYiâ€²|â„±iâˆ’1)|\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Big|\mathbb{E}(\left.Y_{i}Y^{\prime}_{i}\right|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})\Big|
=mnâ€‹Î”nmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â‹…|(âˆ’âˆ‘l=1iâˆ’1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))â€‹ğŸÏ„â‰¥ti+(âˆ‘l=inKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))â€‹ğŸÏ„<ti|\displaystyle\quad=\frac{\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\cdot\left|\Big(-\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\mathbf{1}_{\tau<t_{i}}\right|
â‹…|ğ”¼((Î”iX)2ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}Î”iB|â„±iâˆ’1)|\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\cdot\Big|\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)\Big|
=Î”n2â€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â‹…((âˆ‘l=1iâˆ’1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))â€‹ğŸÏ„â‰¥ti+(âˆ‘l=inKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tlâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))â€‹ğŸÏ„<ti)â€‹oPâ€‹(1)\displaystyle\quad=\Delta_{n}^{2}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\cdot\left(\Big(\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\mathbf{1}_{\tau<t_{i}}\right)o_{P}(1)
=âˆ«01Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(vâˆ’Ï„)â€‹(âˆ«0vKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(sâˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ‘‘sâ€‹ğŸÏ„â‰¥v+âˆ«v1Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(sâˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ‘‘sâ€‹ğŸÏ„<v)â€‹ğ‘‘vâ‹…oPâ€‹(1)â†’ğ‘ƒ0.\displaystyle\quad=\int_{0}^{1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(v-\tau)\Big({\int_{0}^{v}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(s-\tau)ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq v}+{\int_{v}^{1}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(s-\tau)ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau<v}\Big)dv\cdot o_{P}(1)\xrightarrow{P}0.

In view of (27) and (32), one can finally apply Theorem 2.2.15 in [10] to conclude the proof. â™¢\diamondsuit

The next result is the second key ingredient needed for our debiasing method. For an arbitrary fixed Î¶>1\zeta>1, it establishes the convergence rate of the difference Z~nâ€‹(mn,Î¶â€‹vn)âˆ’Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn)\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}), i.e. of c^n,1â€‹(mn,Î¶â€‹vn)âˆ’c^n,1â€‹(mn,vn)\hat{c}_{n,1}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\hat{c}_{n,1}(m_{n},v_{n}) subject to a bias correction, which we exploit in our debiasing procedure.

Theorem 2.

Suppose that 1<Y<21<Y<2, logâ€‹(n)â‰ªmn\sqrt{\mathrm{log}(n)}\ll m_{n}, mn=Oâ€‹(Î”nâˆ’12)m_{n}=O(\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}), Î”nÎ²â‰ªvnâ‰ªÎ”nÎ²â€²\Delta_{n}^{\beta}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\beta^{\prime}} with 14âˆ’Y<Î²â€²<Î²<12\frac{1}{4-Y}<\beta^{\prime}<\beta<\frac{1}{2}, and mnâ†’âˆm_{n}\rightarrow\infty such that vnÎ³â€‹Î”nâˆ’1â‰ªmnâ‰ªÎ”nâˆ’5â€‹vn8+Yv_{n}^{\gamma}\Delta_{n}^{-1}\ll m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y} with some Î³<Y\gamma<Y. Then, under Assumptions 1 and 2, for an arbitrary fixed Î¶>1\zeta>1, we have

unâˆ’1â€‹(Z~nâ€‹(mn,Î¶â€‹vn)âˆ’Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn))â†’ğ’Ÿğ’©â€‹(0,(C++Câˆ’)â€‹|Ï‡Ï„|Y4âˆ’Yâ€‹(Î¶4âˆ’Yâˆ’1)â€‹âˆ«K2â€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘x),\displaystyle u_{n}^{-1}\big(\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\big)\xrightarrow{\mathcal{D}}\mathcal{N}\left(0,\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{\tau}|^{Y}}{4-Y}(\zeta^{4-Y}-1)\int K^{2}(x)dx\right), (34)

as nâ†’âˆn\rightarrow\infty, where un:=Î”nâˆ’1/2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2â†’0u_{n}:=\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}\rightarrow 0.

Remark 4.

The conditions on mnm_{n} in Theorem 2 are stricter than those in Theorem 1 due to the condition Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vnÎ³â‰ªmnâ‰ªÎ”nâˆ’5â€‹vn8+Y\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{\gamma}\ll m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y} (note Î”nâˆ’5â€‹vn8+Yâ‰ªÎ”nâˆ’4â€‹vn4+2â€‹Y\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-4}v_{n}^{4+2Y}, which was the the upper bound for mnm_{n} in Theorem 1). As we shall see, the optimal rate of convergence of the estimation error of our ultimate debiased estimator can be achieved by taking mn=Î¸â€‹Î”nâˆ’1/2m_{n}=\theta\Delta_{n}^{-1/2} for any constant Î¸>0\theta>0 (cf.Â Remark 2). In this bandwidth regime, the additional constraint on mnm_{n} in Theorem 2 reduces to Î”n916+2â€‹Yâ‰ªvnâ‰ªminâ¡(Î”n14âˆ’Y,Î”n12â€‹Î³)\Delta_{n}^{\frac{9}{16+2Y}}\ll v_{n}\ll\min(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}},\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2\gamma}}), whose upper bound and lower bound can be made compatible only if Y<20/11{Y}<20/11.

Proof.

Denote

Zi=mn1/2Î”nâˆ’1/2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2â€‹Kmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹(ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤Î¶â€‹vn}âˆ’ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}),Z_{i}=\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\left(\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq\zeta v_{n}\}}-\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\right),

and note that

unâˆ’1â€‹(Z~nâ€‹(mn,Î¶â€‹vn)âˆ’Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn))\displaystyle u_{n}^{-1}\big(\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\big) =âˆ‘i=1nZiÎ”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)âˆ’unâˆ’1â€‹mnâ€‹(Aâ€‹(Î¶â€‹vn,mn)âˆ’Aâ€‹(vn,mn))\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Z_{i}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-{u_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(A(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})\right)}
=:âˆ‘i=1nÎ¾iÎ”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)\displaystyle=:\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\xi_{i}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}
+(âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Zi|â„±iâˆ’1)Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)âˆ’unâˆ’1â€‹mnâ€‹(Aâ€‹(Î¶â€‹vn,mn)âˆ’Aâ€‹(vn,mn))),\displaystyle\quad+\Big(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Z_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-u_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(A(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})\right)\Big),

where Î¾i:=Ziâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹(Zi|â„±iâˆ’1)\xi_{i}:=Z_{i}-\mathbb{E}(Z_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}). The second term above is oPâ€‹(1)o_{P}(1). Indeed, since mn=Oâ€‹(Î”nâˆ’12)m_{n}=O(\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}), by (16) in Proposition 1,

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Zi|â„±iâˆ’1)Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)âˆ’unâˆ’1â€‹mnâ€‹(Aâ€‹(Î¶â€‹vn,mn)âˆ’Aâ€‹(vn,mn))\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Z_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-u_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}}\big(A({\zeta v_{n}},m_{n})-A({v_{n}},m_{n})\big)
â‰²mn1/2â€‹Î”n2â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’YÎ”nâˆ’1/2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2+mn1/2â€‹oPâ€‹(Î”nâˆ’1/4â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2)Î”nâˆ’1/2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-2-Y}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}+\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{-1/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2})}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}
=mn1/2â€‹Î”n5/2â€‹vnâˆ’4âˆ’Y/2+oPâ€‹(1),\displaystyle\quad=m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{5/2}v_{n}^{-4-Y/2}+o_{P}(1),

which vanishes given our assumption mnâ‰ªÎ”nâˆ’5â€‹vn8+Ym_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y}. Next we obtain the asymptotic behavior for âˆ‘i=1nÎ¾i\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\xi_{i}} by verifying the conditions of Theorem 2.2.15 in [10]. Expression (14) in Proposition 1 yields

Varâ€‹(Î¾i|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle\mathrm{Var}({\xi_{i}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =mnÎ”nâˆ’1â€‹vn4âˆ’YKmnâ€‹Î”n2(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)((Î¶4âˆ’Yâˆ’1)C2,iÎ”nvn4âˆ’Y+oP(Î”nvn4âˆ’Y)\displaystyle=\frac{m_{n}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y}}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\Big((\zeta^{4-Y}-1){C_{2,i}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y}+{o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})}
âˆ’{(Î¶2âˆ’Yâˆ’1)C1,iÎ”nvn2âˆ’Y+(Î¶âˆ’Yâˆ’1)D1,iÎ”n2vnâˆ’Y+OP(Î”n3vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)}2)\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\quad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad-\big\{(\zeta^{2-Y}-1){C_{1,i}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}+(\zeta^{-Y}-1){D_{1,i}}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}+{O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})}\big\}^{2}\Big)
=mnÎ”nâˆ’1â€‹vn4âˆ’Yâ€‹Kmnâ€‹Î”n2â€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹((Î¶4âˆ’Yâˆ’1)â€‹C2,iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn4âˆ’Y+oPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn4âˆ’Y)),\displaystyle=\frac{m_{n}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y}}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big((\zeta^{4-Y}-1){C_{2,i}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y}+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})\big),

where C2,i=(C++Câˆ’)â€‹|Ï‡tiâˆ’1|Y4âˆ’YC_{2,i}=\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{t_{i-1}}|^{Y}}{4-Y}. Therefore, with 1<Y<21<Y<2 and vnâ‰ªÎ”n1/(4âˆ’Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}, we obtain

s2â€‹n2\displaystyle s_{2n}^{2} :=âˆ‘i=1nVarâ€‹(Î¾i|â„±iâˆ’1)\displaystyle:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathrm{Var}({\xi_{i}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})
=mnâ€‹Î”n2â€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”n2â€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(C++Câˆ’)â€‹|Ï‡tiâˆ’1|Y4âˆ’Yâ€‹(Î¶4âˆ’Yâˆ’1)+oPâ€‹(1)\displaystyle=m_{n}\Delta_{n}^{2}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{t_{i-1}}|^{Y}}{4-Y}(\zeta^{{4-Y}}-1)+o_{P}(1)
âŸ¶(C++Câˆ’)â€‹|Ï‡Ï„|Y4âˆ’Yâ€‹(Î¶4âˆ’Yâˆ’1)â€‹âˆ«K2â€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘x.\displaystyle\longrightarrow\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{\tau}|^{Y}}{4-Y}(\zeta^{{4-Y}}-1)\int K^{2}(x)dx.

And consequently, with (26), we have

s2â€‹n2(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))2â†’(C++Câˆ’)â€‹|Ï‡Ï„|Y4âˆ’Yâ€‹(Î¶4âˆ’Yâˆ’1)â€‹âˆ«K2â€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘x.\frac{s_{2n}^{2}}{\big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)\big)^{2}}\rightarrow\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{\tau}|^{Y}}{4-Y}(\zeta^{{4-Y}}-1)\int K^{2}(x)dx. (35)

Similarly, for any p>2p>2, we have444By a standard localization argument, we may assume that Ïƒ\sigma is bounded.

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â€‹(Î¾ip|â„±iâˆ’1)(Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„))p\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}({\xi_{i}^{p}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\big(\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)\big)^{p}}} â‰²mnp/2Î”nâˆ’p/2â€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’pâ€‹Y/2â€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”npâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y+Î”np)\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{m_{n}^{p/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-p/2}v_{n}^{2p-pY/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K^{p}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{p})
â‰²vn(p/2âˆ’1)â€‹Ymnp/2âˆ’1â€‹Î”np/2âˆ’1â€‹âˆ«Kpâ€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘x+Î”np/2mnp/2âˆ’1â€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’pâ€‹Y/2â€‹âˆ«Kpâ€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘x.\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{v_{n}^{(p/2-1)Y}}{m_{n}^{p/2-1}\Delta_{n}^{p/2-1}}\int K^{p}(x)dx+\frac{\Delta_{n}^{p/2}}{m_{n}^{p/2-1}v_{n}^{2p-pY/2}}\int K^{p}(x)dx. (36)

In (36) the first term vanishes for any p>2p>2 since mnâˆ’1â€‹Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vnYâ†’0m_{n}^{-1}\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{Y}\rightarrow 0. For the second term, note that it can be written as (mn1/pâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vnâˆ’2â€‹Î”nâˆ’1/2â€‹mnâˆ’1/2â€‹vnY/2)p\Big(m_{n}^{1/p}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-2}\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}m_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{Y/2}\Big)^{p}. By taking pâ†“2p\downarrow 2, the second term vanishes given Î”nâ€‹vnâˆ’2â‰²Î”n1âˆ’2â€‹Î²â†’0\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-2}\lesssim\Delta_{n}^{1-2\beta}\rightarrow 0 with Î²<12\beta<\frac{1}{2} and mnâˆ’1â€‹Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vnYâ†’0m_{n}^{-1}\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{Y}\rightarrow 0.

In view of (36) and (35), what remains is to check the martingale technical condition from Theorem 2.2.15 in [10]. Specifically, due to (26), it requires us to show that as nâ†’âˆn\to\infty,

âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[Î¾iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹M]=âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[Ziâ€‹Î”nâ€‹M]â€‹â†’ğ‘ƒâ€‹0,{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\xi_{i}\Delta_{n}M\right]}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[Z_{i}\Delta_{n}M\right]\overset{P}{\to}0,

when M=WM=W or MM is a bounded martingale orthogonal to WW. Equivalently, it suffices to prove that

mn1/2Î”nâˆ’1/2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2â€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹fâ€‹(Î”iâ€‹X)â€‹Î”iâ€‹M]=oPâ€‹(1),\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}f(\Delta_{i}X)\Delta_{i}M\right]=o_{P}(1),

where fâ€‹(x):=ğŸ{vn<|x|â‰¤Î¶â€‹vn}f(x):=\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}<|x|\leq\zeta v_{n}\}}. Similar to the proof of Lemma 12 in [3], there exists a C2C^{2} smooth approximation fnf_{n} of ff such that for any Î·>0\eta>0,

ğŸ{vnâ€‹(1+23â€‹vnÎ·)<|x|<Î¶â€‹vnâ€‹(1âˆ’23â€‹vnÎ·)}â‰¤fnâ€‹(x)â‰¤ğŸ{vnâ€‹(1+13â€‹vnÎ·)<|x|<Î¶â€‹vnâ€‹(1âˆ’13â€‹vnÎ·)},\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}(1+\frac{2}{3}v_{n}^{\eta})<|x|<\zeta v_{n}(1-\frac{2}{3}v_{n}^{\eta})\}}\leq f_{n}(x)\leq\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}(1+\frac{1}{3}v_{n}^{\eta})<|x|<\zeta v_{n}(1-\frac{1}{3}v_{n}^{\eta})\}},
|fnâ€²â€‹(x)|â‰¤Cvn1+Î·,|fnâ€²â€²â€‹(x)|â‰¤Cvn2+2â€‹Î·.|f^{\prime}_{n}(x)|\leq\frac{C}{v_{n}^{1+\eta}},\quad|f^{\prime\prime}_{n}(x)|\leq\frac{C}{v_{n}^{2+2\eta}}.

Then, the result follows from the following two limits

mn1/2Î”nâˆ’1/2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2â€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹(fâˆ’fn)â€‹(Î”iâ€‹X)â€‹Î”iâ€‹M]â†’0,\displaystyle\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}(f-f_{n})(\Delta_{i}X)\Delta_{i}M\right]\to 0, (37)

and

mn1/2Î”nâˆ’1/2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2â€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹fnâ€‹(Î”iâ€‹X)â€‹Î”iâ€‹M]=oPâ€‹(1).\displaystyle\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}f_{n}(\Delta_{i}X)\Delta_{i}M\right]=o_{P}(1). (38)

While the proof of (37) is relatively straightforward, the proof of (38) is nontrivial and lengthy. This is shown in Appendix A.3.

â™¢\diamondsuit

Finally we are ready to formally construct our debiasing estimators. Our debiasing steps follow the same idea as in [12]. Write Î¶â†’k=(Î¶1,â€¦,Î¶k)\vec{\zeta}_{k}=(\zeta_{1},\dots,\zeta_{k}), where Î¶1,â€¦,Î¶k>1\zeta_{1},\dots,\zeta_{k}>1 are fixed constants. Let

c~n(k)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’k)\displaystyle\widetilde{c}^{(k)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) :=c~n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)\displaystyle:=\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})
âˆ’(c~n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,Î¶kâ€‹vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)âˆ’c~n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1))2c~n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,Î¶k2â€‹vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)âˆ’2â€‹c~n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,Î¶kâ€‹vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)+c~n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1),\displaystyle\quad-\frac{\big(\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})\big)^{2}}{\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}^{2}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-2\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})+\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})}, (39)

for each kâ‰¥1k\geq 1, with c~n(0)â€‹(mn,vn)=c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)\widetilde{c}^{(0)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})=\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}). Our next theorem is the second main result of this paper; it establishes a CLT for the feasible estimator c~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’2)\widetilde{c}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}).

Theorem 3.

Let

Z~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) :=mnâ€‹(c~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’2)âˆ’c^n,2â€‹(mn)).\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2})-\hat{c}_{n,2}(m_{n})\Big).

Then, under the assumptions and notation of Theorems 1 and 2, as nâ†’âˆn\rightarrow\infty,

(Z~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn),Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn))â†’sâ€‹t(Z1,Z2).\displaystyle(\tilde{Z}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}),\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}))\xrightarrow{st}\mathcal{(}Z_{1},{Z_{2}}). (40)

Furthermore, if we set

mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’Î¸,withÎ¸âˆˆ[0,âˆ),m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\rightarrow\theta,\quad\text{with}\quad\theta\in{[0,\infty)},

we have the following stable convergence in law, as nâ†’âˆn\rightarrow\infty:

mnâ€‹(c~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’2)âˆ’ÏƒÏ„2)â†’sâ€‹tZ1+Î¸â€‹Z2.\sqrt{m_{n}}(\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2})\xrightarrow{st}Z_{1}+\theta{Z_{2}}. (41)
Remark 5.

Recall that Remark 2 identifies two bandwidth regimes of primary importance: (i) 0<Î¸<âˆ0<\theta<\infty, and (ii) Î¸=0\theta=0, both with a convergence rate dictated by mnâˆ’1/2.m_{n}^{-1/2}. In case (i), a rate-optimal (feasible) CLT for c~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’2)\tilde{c}_{n}^{(2)}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}) is attained in (41) since mnâˆ’1/2â‰Î”n1/4m_{n}^{-1/2}\asymp\Delta_{n}^{1/4}, provided 1â‰¤Y<20/111\leq Y<20/11, but no CLT is available in case (i) when Yâ‰¥20/11Y\geq 20/11. In case (ii), the rate is strictly slower than Î”n1/4\Delta_{n}^{1/4} (see Remark 2 for details), but a CLT still holds for c~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}) even when 20/11â‰¤Y<220/11\leq Y<2 at the expense of a deteriorating rate. Indeed, since mnâ‰ªÎ”nâˆ’5â€‹vn8+Ym_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y} and vnâ‰ªÎ”n14âˆ’Yv_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}}, we have mnâ‰ªÎ”n(6â€‹Yâˆ’12)/(4âˆ’Y)m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{(6Y-12)/(4-Y)} and hence mnâˆ’1/2â‰«Î”n(6âˆ’3â€‹Y)/(4âˆ’Y)m_{n}^{-1/2}\gg\Delta_{n}^{(6-3Y)/(4-Y)}, which tends to zero more slowly as YY gets closer to 22.

Remark 6.

In Theorem 3, we proceeded with a two-step debiasing procedure to iteratively remove bias terms in Aâ€‹(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) one at a time. However, if the second-order term in (19) is negligible when multiplied by unâˆ’1â€‹mnu_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}} (and, thus, (34) is valid replacing Aâ€‹(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) with only the first-order term âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹C1,iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Y\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}), then only one debiasing step is needed. Specifically, for one-step debiasing it suffices that

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹C1,iâ€‹Î”n2â€‹vnâˆ’Yâ‰ª1.\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}\ll 1.

Therefore, we only require that unâˆ’1â€‹mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vnâˆ’Yâ‰ª1u_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-Y}\ll 1 or, equivalently, mnâ‰ªÎ”nâˆ’3â€‹vnY+4m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-3}v_{n}^{Y+4}. In the optimal-rate bandwidth regime mnâ‰Î”nâˆ’1/2m_{n}\asymp\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}, this imposes the relation Î”n52â€‹(Y+4)â‰ªvn\Delta_{n}^{\frac{5}{2(Y+4)}}\ll v_{n}, but since vnâ‰ªÎ”n14âˆ’Yv_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}}, this yields the restriction Y<12/7Y<12/7. Similarly as in Remark 5, if Yâ‰¥12/7Y\geq 12/7 and Î¸=0\theta=0, the one-step debiased estimator c~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1}) will still enjoy a CLT centered at ÏƒÏ„2\sigma_{\tau}^{2}, but with a rate strictly slower than Î”n4âˆ’2â€‹Y4âˆ’Y\Delta_{n}^{\frac{4-2Y}{4-Y}}, which tends to zero more slowly as YY gets closer to 22.

Proof.

Denote â„={(1,1),(2,1)}\mathcal{I}=\{(1,1),(2,1)\} and recall that

Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn)=mnâ€‹(c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)âˆ’Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)âˆ’Aâ€‹(vn,mn)),\displaystyle\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})=\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\frac{\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}-{A(v_{n},m_{n})}\right), (42)

where

A(vn,mn)=âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹C1,iâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’YÎ”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)+âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹D1,iâ€‹Î”n2â€‹vnâˆ’YÎ”nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tjâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)=:âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆâ„ai,j(vn).\displaystyle A(v_{n},{m_{n}})=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}+\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){D_{1,i}}{\Delta_{n}^{2}}v_{n}^{-Y}}{{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}}=:\sum_{(i,j)\in\mathcal{I}}a_{i,j}(v_{n}).

We introduce the following notation:

Î·i,jâ€‹(Î¶):=Î¶2âˆ’2â€‹(iâˆ’j)âˆ’jâ€‹Yâˆ’1,\displaystyle\eta_{i,j}(\zeta)=\zeta^{2-2(i-j)-jY}-1,
Î¨n:=unâˆ’1â€‹(Z~nâ€‹(Î¶12â€‹mn,vn)âˆ’2â€‹Z~nâ€‹(Î¶1â€‹mn,vn)+Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn))=OPâ€‹(1),\displaystyle\Psi_{n}=u_{n}^{-1}\big(\tilde{Z}_{n}(\zeta_{1}^{2}m_{n},v_{n})-2\tilde{Z}_{n}(\zeta_{1}m_{n},v_{n})+\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\big)=O_{P}(1),
Î¦n:=unâˆ’1â€‹(Z~nâ€‹(Î¶â€‹mn,vn)âˆ’Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn))=OPâ€‹(1),\displaystyle\Phi_{n}=u_{n}^{-1}\big(\tilde{Z}_{n}(\zeta m_{n},v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\big)=O_{P}(1),

where OPâ€‹(1)O_{P}(1) is a consequence of Theorem 2. Note that, for any (i,j)(i,j) we have

ai,jâ€‹(Î¶â€‹vn)âˆ’ai,jâ€‹(vn)=Î·i,jâ€‹(Î¶)â€‹ai,jâ€‹(vn),\displaystyle a_{i,j}(\zeta v_{n})-a_{i,j}(v_{n})=\eta_{i,j}(\zeta)a_{i,j}(v_{n}), (43)
ai,jâ€‹(Î¶2â€‹vn)âˆ’2â€‹ai,jâ€‹(Î¶â€‹vn)+ai,jâ€‹(vn)=Î·i,j2â€‹(Î¶)â€‹ai,jâ€‹(vn).\displaystyle a_{i,j}(\zeta^{2}v_{n})-2a_{i,j}(\zeta v_{n})+a_{i,j}(v_{n})=\eta_{i,j}^{2}(\zeta)a_{i,j}(v_{n}).

Recall Î”nâ€‹vnâˆ’2â‰ª1\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-2}\ll 1 gives the order comparison:

a1,1â€‹(vn)â‰«a2,1â€‹(vn).\displaystyle a_{1,1}(v_{n})\gg a_{2,1}(v_{n}). (44)

In the first stage of debiasing, the leading order term a1,1â€‹(vn)a_{1,1}(v_{n}) is removed.

First step: removal of a1,1â€‹(vn)a_{1,1}(v_{n})

Let

c~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶1)\displaystyle\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1}) =c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)âˆ’(c^nâ€‹(mn,Î¶1â€‹vn)âˆ’c^nâ€‹(mn,vn))2c^nâ€‹(mn,Î¶12â€‹vn)âˆ’2â€‹c^nâ€‹(mn,Î¶1â€‹vn)+c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)\displaystyle=\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\frac{\Big(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{1}v_{n})-\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\Big)^{2}}{{\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{1}^{2}v_{n})}-2\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{1}v_{n})+\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})}
=:c^n(mn,vn)âˆ’a^1,1(vn).\displaystyle=:\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n}). (45)

Note that, due to (42)-(3),

c^nâ€‹(mn,Î¶â€‹vn)âˆ’c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)\displaystyle\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) =mnâˆ’1/2â€‹(Z~nâ€‹(mn,Î¶â€‹vn)âˆ’Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn))+Anâ€‹(Î¶â€‹vn,mn)âˆ’Anâ€‹(vn,mn)\displaystyle=m_{n}^{-1/2}\left(\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\right)+A_{n}(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})-A_{n}(v_{n},m_{n})
=mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¦n+Anâ€‹(Î¶â€‹vn,mn)âˆ’Anâ€‹(vn,mn).\displaystyle=m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Phi_{n}+A_{n}(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})-A_{n}(v_{n},m_{n}).

Similarly, we can write:

c^nâ€‹(mn,Î¶2â€‹vn)âˆ’2â€‹c^nâ€‹(mn,Î¶â€‹vn)+c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)\displaystyle\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta^{2}v_{n})-2\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})+\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) =mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¨n+Anâ€‹(Î¶2â€‹vn,mn)âˆ’2â€‹Anâ€‹(Î¶â€‹vn,mn)+Anâ€‹(vn,mn).\displaystyle=m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}+A_{n}(\zeta^{2}v_{n},m_{n})-2A_{n}(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})+A_{n}(v_{n},m_{n}).

Then, in the light of Proposition 1 and (43), we may expand a^1,1â€‹(vn)\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n}) as follows:

a^1,1â€‹(vn)\displaystyle\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n}) =(âˆ‘(r,s)âˆˆâ„Î·r,sâ€‹ar,sâ€‹(vn)+mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¦n)2âˆ‘(r,s)âˆˆâ„Î·r,s2â€‹ar,sâ€‹(vn)+mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¨n\displaystyle=\frac{\big(\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}\eta_{r,s}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Phi_{n}\big)^{2}}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}\eta^{2}_{r,s}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}} (46)
=a1,1â€‹(vn)+OPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un)\displaystyle=a_{1,1}(v_{n})+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})
+Î·2,1â€‹a2,1â€‹(vn)â€‹(2â€‹Î·1,1âˆ’Î·2,1)â€‹a1,1+Î·2,1â€‹a2,1â€‹(vn)Î·1,12â€‹a1,1â€‹(vn)+Î·2,12â€‹a2,1â€‹(vn)+mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¨n,\displaystyle\quad+\eta_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})\frac{(2\eta_{1,1}-\eta_{2,1})a_{1,1}+\eta_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})}{\eta^{2}_{1,1}a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\eta^{2}_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})+m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}},

where OPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un)O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}) includes the cross products between âˆ‘(r,s)âˆˆâ„Î·r,sâ€‹ar,sâ€‹(vn)\sum_{(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}}\eta_{r,s}a_{r,s}(v_{n}) and mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¦n=oPâ€‹(1)m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Phi_{n}=o_{P}(1), along with (mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¦n)2(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Phi_{n})^{2} and mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¨nâ€‹a1,1m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}a_{1,1}, all divided by âˆ‘(r,s)âˆˆâ„Î·r,s2â€‹ar,sâ€‹(vn)+mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¨n\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}\eta^{2}_{r,s}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}.

To simplify the last term in (46), note that for any variable N=opâ€‹(a1,12â€‹(vn))N=o_{p}\big(a_{1,1}^{2}(v_{n})\big),

Nâˆ‘(r,s)âˆˆâ„ar,sâ€‹(vn)+Opâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un)âˆ’Nâˆ‘(r,s)âˆˆâ„ar,sâ€‹(vn)\displaystyle\frac{N}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+O_{p}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})}-\frac{N}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}a_{r,s}(v_{n})}
=âˆ’Nâˆ‘(r,s)âˆˆâ„ar,sâ€‹(vn)â‹…OPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un)(âˆ‘(r,s)âˆˆâ„ar,sâ€‹(vn)+OPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un))\displaystyle\quad=-\frac{N}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}a_{r,s}(v_{n})}\cdot\frac{O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})}{\big(\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})\big)}
=âˆ’Na1,12â€‹(vn)â€‹(1+opâ€‹(1))â‹…OPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un)\displaystyle\quad=\frac{-N}{a_{1,1}^{2}(v_{n})(1+o_{p}(1))}\cdot O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})
=oPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un),\displaystyle\quad=o_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}), (47)

where above, for simplicity, we omitted the coefficients associated with ai,jâ€‹(vn)a_{i,j}(v_{n}). The above shows that we can drop the term mnâˆ’1/2â€‹unâ€‹Î¨nm_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n} in the denominator and can write (46) as follows

a^1,1â€‹(vn)\displaystyle\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n}) =a1,1â€‹(vn)+OPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un)\displaystyle=a_{1,1}(v_{n})+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})
+Î·2,1â€‹a2,1â€‹(vn)â€‹(2â€‹Î·1,1âˆ’Î·2,1)â€‹a1,1+Î·2,1â€‹a2,1â€‹(vn)Î·1,12â€‹a1,1â€‹(vn)+Î·2,12â€‹a2,1â€‹(vn)\displaystyle\quad+\eta_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})\frac{(2\eta_{1,1}-\eta_{2,1})a_{1,1}+\eta_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})}{\eta^{2}_{1,1}a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\eta^{2}_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})}
=a1,1â€‹(vn)+Î·~2,1â€‹a2,1+Î·Ë˜2,1â€‹a2,12â€‹(vn)Î·1,12â€‹a1,1â€‹(vn)+Î·2,12â€‹a2,1â€‹(vn)+OPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un),\displaystyle=a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\tilde{\eta}_{2,1}a_{2,1}+\breve{\eta}_{2,1}\frac{a_{2,1}^{2}(v_{n})}{\eta^{2}_{1,1}a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\eta^{2}_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})}+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}),

for some constants Î·~2,1\tilde{\eta}_{2,1} and Î·Ë˜2,1\breve{\eta}_{2,1}. Note that the third term above is OPâ€‹(a2,12/a1,1)O_{P}(a_{2,1}^{2}/a_{1,1}) and, thus, this term is oPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un)o_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}) due to our assumption mnâ‰ªÎ”nâˆ’5â€‹vn8+Ym_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y}. We conclude that

a^1,1â€‹(vn)=a1,1â€‹(vn)+Î·~2,1â€‹a2,1â€‹(vn)+OPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un).\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n})=a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\tilde{\eta}_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}). (48)

We now show the first debiasing step eliminates a1,1â€‹(vn)a_{1,1}(v_{n}). Indeed, denoting a~2,1â€‹(vn):=(1âˆ’Î·~2,1)â€‹a2,1â€‹(vn)\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n}):=(1-\tilde{\eta}_{2,1})a_{2,1}(v_{n}), in light of (42), (3), and (48) and recalling that Aâ€‹(vn,mn)=a1,1+a1,2A(v_{n},m_{n})=a_{1,1}+a_{1,2}, we see that

Z~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}^{(1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) :=mnâ€‹(c~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶1)âˆ’a~2,1â€‹(vn)âˆ’Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12)\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1})-\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)
=mnâ€‹(c^nâ€‹(mn,vn)âˆ’a^1,1â€‹(vn)âˆ’a~2,1â€‹(vn)âˆ’Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12)\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n})-\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)
=Z~nâ€‹(mn,vn)+OPâ€‹(un).\displaystyle=\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})+O_{P}(u_{n}).

Therefore, (20) implies that

(Z~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn),Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn))â†’sâ€‹t(Z1,Z2).\displaystyle(\tilde{Z}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n}),\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}))\xrightarrow{st}\mathcal{(}Z_{1},Z_{2}). (49)

Second step: removal of a2,1â€‹(vn)a_{2,1}(v_{n})

Similar to (3), we can define
