c~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶2,Î¶1)\displaystyle\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(2)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{2},\zeta_{1}) =c~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶1)âˆ’(c~n(1)â€‹(mn,Î¶2â€‹vn,Î¶1)âˆ’c~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶1))2c~n(1)â€‹(mn,Î¶22â€‹vn,Î¶1)âˆ’2â€‹c~n(1)â€‹(mn,Î¶2â€‹vn,Î¶1)+c~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶1)\displaystyle=\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1})-\frac{\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},\zeta_{2}v_{n},\zeta_{1})-\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1})\Big)^{2}}{\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},\zeta_{2}^{2}v_{n},\zeta_{1})-2\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},\zeta_{2}v_{n},\zeta_{1})+\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1})}
=:c~n(1)(mn,Î¶2vn,Î¶1)âˆ’a^2,1(vn).\displaystyle=:\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},\zeta_{2}v_{n},\zeta_{1})-\hat{a}_{2,1}(v_{n}). (50)

Similar to (46), we may expand a^2,1â€‹(vn)\hat{a}_{2,1}(v_{n}) as follows:

a^2,1â€‹(vn)=a~2,1â€‹(vn)+OPâ€‹(mnâˆ’1/2â€‹un).\displaystyle\hat{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})={\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})}+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}). (51)

Then we see that

Z~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) :=mnâ€‹(c~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶2,Î¶1)âˆ’Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12)\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(2)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{2},\zeta_{1})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)
=mnâ€‹(c~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶2,Î¶1)âˆ’a^2,1â€‹(vn)âˆ’Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12)\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{2},\zeta_{1})-\hat{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)
=mnâ€‹(c~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶2,Î¶1)âˆ’a~2,1â€‹(vn)âˆ’Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12)+OPâ€‹(un)\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{2},\zeta_{1})-\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)+O_{P}(u_{n})
=Z~n(1)â€‹(mn,vn)+OPâ€‹(un).\displaystyle=\tilde{Z}^{(1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})+O_{P}(u_{n}). (52)

Again, (49) now implies that

(Z~n(2)â€‹(mn,vn),Z~nâ€²â€‹(mn))â†’sâ€‹t(Z1,Z2).\displaystyle(\tilde{Z}_{n}^{(2)}(m_{n},v_{n}),\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}))\xrightarrow{st}\mathcal{(}Z_{1},Z_{2}). (53)

To conclude the last two statements of the theorem, we follow the same arguments as in Remark 2. â™¢\diamondsuit

4 Simulation

In the numerical experiments below, we evaluate the performance of our debiased estimators under a Heston-type volatility model in two different settings. First, for comparison, we replicate the parameter setting and sampling scheme used in [15], which incorporates a symmetric stable jump component, although this configuration is arguably unrealistic for most financial applications (e.g., the overall annualized volatility is set to 1). Second, we consider a parameter setting that better reflects the empirical features of financial data. In this case, we also truncate the increments of the stable LÃ©vy process, as is commonly done in applications, and investigate the impact of different choices of the threshold parameter vnv_{n}.

4.1 Simulation with Stable Jump Component

Following [15], we consider the following model:

Xt\displaystyle X_{t} =X0+âˆ«0tbtâ€‹ğ‘‘t+âˆ«0tVsâ€‹ğ‘‘Ws+Jt,\displaystyle=X_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}b_{t}dt+\int_{0}^{t}\sqrt{V_{s}}\,dW_{s}+J_{t}, (54)
Vt\displaystyle V_{t} =V0+âˆ«0tÎºâ€‹(Î¸âˆ’Vs)â€‹ğ‘‘s+Î¾â€‹âˆ«0tVsâ€‹ğ‘‘Bs,\displaystyle=V_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\kappa(\theta-V_{s})ds+\xi\int_{0}^{t}\sqrt{V_{s}}\,dB_{s},

where BB and Bâ€²B^{\prime} are correlated standard Brownian motions with correlation Ï\rho, JJ is a strictly symmetric stable LÃ©vy process 555The rstable package in R was used to simulate the YY-stable portion of the jump component in all cases. with Blumenthal-Getoor index YY and scale parameter 11 (note [15] includes an additional finite-activity component which we omit for simplicity). In this section, we take the same parameter values as in [15]:

X0=1,V0=0,Ï=0,btâ‰¡1,Îº=0.03,Î¸=1,Î¾=1.5.X_{0}=1,\quad V_{0}=0,\quad\rho=0,\quad b_{t}\equiv 1,\quad\kappa=0.03,\quad\theta=1,\quad\xi=1.5.

In this simulation, we compare the performance of our estimator c^â€‹(mn,vn)\hat{c}(m_{n},v_{n}) defined in (3), c~(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{1}) and c~n,Ï„(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}) defined in (3) to the estimators Ïƒ^Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) and Ïƒ~Ï„,n2â€‹(Î»,un,h)\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) introduced in [15], which are based on the empirical characteristic approach of [12]. Specifically, Ïƒ^Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)666[15] defines Ïƒ^Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)=ÏƒÂ¯Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)âˆ’2â€‹hun2â€‹Î”nâ€‹(sinhâ¡(ÏƒÂ¯Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)))2\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)=\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)-\frac{2h}{u_{n}^{2}\Delta_{n}}(\sinh(\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)))^{2} for simulation. The difference lies in the reciprocal placement of hh and Î”n\Delta_{n} in the bias correction term. We interpret the version in [15] as a likely typo and instead follow the formulation consistent with [12]. and Ïƒ~Ï„,n2â€‹(Î»,un,h)\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) are defined as

Ïƒ^Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)\displaystyle\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) =ÏƒÂ¯Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)âˆ’2â€‹Î”nun2â€‹hâ€‹(sinhâ¡(ÏƒÂ¯Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)))2,\displaystyle=\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)-\frac{2\Delta_{n}}{u_{n}^{2}h}(\sinh(\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)))^{2},
Ïƒ~Ï„,n2â€‹(Î»,un,h)\displaystyle\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) =Ïƒ^Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)âˆ’B~Ï„,nâ€‹(Î»,un,h),\displaystyle=\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)-\tilde{B}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h),

where

ÏƒÂ¯Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)\displaystyle\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) =âˆ’2un2â€‹logâ€‹(SÏ„,nâ€‹(un,h)âˆ¨Î”nh),\displaystyle=\frac{-2}{u_{n}^{2}}\mathrm{log}\left(S_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)\vee\sqrt{\frac{\Delta_{n}}{h}}\right),
SÏ„,nâ€‹(un,h)\displaystyle S_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) =Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKhâ€‹(iâ€‹Î”nâˆ’Ï„)â€‹cosâ¡(unâ€‹Î”iâ€‹XÎ”n),\displaystyle=\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{h}(i\Delta_{n}-\tau)\cos\left(\frac{u_{n}\Delta_{i}X}{\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}}\right),

and B~Ï„,nâ€‹(Î»,un,h)\tilde{B}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) is a bias-correction term777The formula of B~Ï„,nâ€‹(Î»,un,h)\tilde{B}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) in [15] forces each summand in the denominator to be nonpositive. However, in our experiments, we found that omitting control of the sign of these terms significantly improved the performance of the estimators.

B~Ï„,nâ€‹(Î»,un,h)\displaystyle\tilde{B}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) =âˆ‘i=1âŒŠ1mnâ€‹Î”nâŒ‹[Ïƒ^(iâˆ’1)â€‹mnâ€‹Î”n,n2â€‹(Î»â€‹pâ€‹un,h)âˆ’Ïƒ^(iâˆ’1)â€‹mnâ€‹Î”n,n2â€‹(pâ€‹un,h)]â‹…[(Ïƒ^Ï„,n2â€‹(Î»â€‹un,h)âˆ’Ïƒ^Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h))âˆ§0]âˆ‘i=1âŒŠ1mnâ€‹Î”nâŒ‹(Ïƒ^(iâˆ’1)â€‹mnâ€‹Î”n,n2(Î»2pun,h)âˆ’2Ïƒ^(iâˆ’1)â€‹mnâ€‹Î”n,n2((Î»pun,h)+Ïƒ^(iâˆ’1)â€‹mnâ€‹Î”n,n2(pun,h)),\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\rfloor}\left[{\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}(\lambda pu_{n},h)-{\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}(pu_{n},h)\right]\cdot{\left[(\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda u_{n},h)-\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h))\wedge 0\right]}}{\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\rfloor}\big({\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}(\lambda^{2}pu_{n},h)-2{\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}((\lambda pu_{n},h)+{\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}(pu_{n},h)\big)},

which aggregates spot estimators across tt for improved finite-sample performance. This approach was also used in [12].

For comparison, for our one- and two-step debiased estimators c~m,Ï„(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}_{m,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{1}) and c~n,Ï„(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}), we also adopt the debiasing adjustments of [15] and [12] described above. Specifically, denoting c~n,Ï„(k)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’k)\tilde{c}^{(k)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) the estimator c~n(k)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’k)\tilde{c}^{(k)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) at time Ï„\tau, we consider

c~n,Ï„(k)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’k)\displaystyle\widetilde{c}^{(k)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) :=c~n,Ï„(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)\displaystyle:=\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})
âˆ’(An(k)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’k)âˆ¨0)â€‹(c~n,Ï„(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,Î¶kâ€‹vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)âˆ’c~n,Ï„(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1))âˆ¨0,\displaystyle\quad-\big(A^{(k)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k})\vee 0\big)\big(\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})\big)\vee 0,

where An(k):=An(k)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’k)A^{(k)}_{{n}}:=A^{(k)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) is given by

An(k)=Â±âˆ‘i=1âŒŠ1mnâ€‹Î”nâŒ‹(c~n,iâ€‹mnâ€‹Î”n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,Î¶kâ€‹pkâ€‹vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)âˆ’c~n,iâ€‹mnâ€‹Î”n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,pkâ€‹vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1))âˆ‘i=1âŒŠ1mnâ€‹Î”nâŒ‹(c~n,iâ€‹mnâ€‹Î”n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,Î¶k2â€‹pkâ€‹vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)âˆ’2â€‹c~n,iâ€‹mnâ€‹Î”n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,Î¶kâ€‹pkâ€‹vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)+c~n,iâ€‹mnâ€‹Î”n(kâˆ’1)â€‹(mn,pkâ€‹vn,Î¶â†’kâˆ’1)),A_{n}^{(k)}=\pm\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\rfloor}\big(\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})\big)}{\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\rfloor}\big(\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}^{2}p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-2\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})+\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})\big)},

where the sign of the bias terms are chosen as in [3] and cn,Ï„(0)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’0)=c^â€‹(mn,vn)c^{(0)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{0})=\hat{c}(m_{n},v_{n}) at Ï„\tau, i.e., An(1)A_{n}^{(1)} is positive and An(2)A_{n}^{(2)} is negative, so as to ensure compatibility with the theoretical sign of the terms in Aâ€‹(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}).

To evaluate estimation performance, we simulate MM independent paths and aggregate various pathwise error measures computed along each simulated path for each of the estimators considered above. Denoting the true value of the spot variance at tit_{i} in the jj-th path as Ïƒti,j2:=Vti,j\sigma^{2}_{t_{i},j}:=V_{t_{i},j} and a given estimator as Ïƒ^ti,j2\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{t_{i},j}, we consider an estimate of the pathwise root mean squared error (RMSE) on the time grid {li=iâ€‹âŒŠn/100âŒ‹}i=10,â€¦,90\{l_{i}=i\lfloor n/100\rfloor\}_{i=10,\dots,90} as follows:

Râ€‹Mâ€‹Sâ€‹E^:=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘j=1MMâ€‹Sâ€‹Ej,\widehat{RMSE}:=\sqrt{\frac{1}{M}\sum_{{j=1}}^{M}MSE_{j}}\,,

where Mâ€‹Sâ€‹Ej:=181â€‹âˆ‘i=1090(Ïƒ^li,j2âˆ’Ïƒli,j2)2MSE_{j}:=\frac{1}{81}\sum_{i=10}^{90}(\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{l_{i},j}-\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j})^{2}. Similarly, we also consider the mean absolute relative error Aâ€‹Râ€‹E^\widehat{ARE} and the mean relative error Râ€‹E^\widehat{RE}:

Aâ€‹Râ€‹E^:=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘j=1MAâ€‹Ejâ€‹Â andÂ â€‹Râ€‹E^:=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘j=1MEj,\widehat{ARE}:=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{j=1}^{M}AE_{j}\;\text{ and }\;\widehat{RE}:=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{j=1}^{M}E_{j},

where Aâ€‹Ej:=181â€‹âˆ‘i=1090|Ïƒ^li,j2âˆ’Ïƒli,j2|/Ïƒli,j2AE_{j}:=\frac{1}{81}\sum_{i=10}^{90}|\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{l_{i},j}-\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j}|/\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j} and Ej:=181â€‹âˆ‘i=1090(Ïƒ^li,j2âˆ’Ïƒli,j2)/Ïƒli,j2E_{j}:=\frac{1}{81}\sum_{i=10}^{90}(\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{l_{i},j}-\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j})/\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j}.

For our estimators c^nâ€‹(mn,Î”n)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\Delta_{n}), c~m,Ï„(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}_{m,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{1}) and c~n,Ï„(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}), we use the exponential kernel Kâ€‹(x)=expâ¡(âˆ’|x|)/2K(x)=\exp({-|x|})/2 as well as the two-sided uniform kernel Gâ€‹(x)=ğŸâˆ’1â‰¤|x|â‰¤1/2G(x)=\mathbf{1}_{-1\leq|x|\leq 1}/2, and set mn=Î”nâˆ’1/2m_{n}=\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}, vn=Bâ€‹Vâ€‹Î”n5/12v_{n}=\sqrt{BV}\Delta_{n}^{5/12}, where Bâ€‹V=Ï€2â€‹âˆ‘i=2n|Î”iâ€‹X|â€‹|Î”iâˆ’1â€‹X|/TBV=\frac{\pi}{2}\sum_{i=2}^{n}|\Delta_{i}X||\Delta_{i-1}X|/T is the bipower estimator for the integrated volatility. For the estimators Ïƒ^Ï„,n2â€‹(un,h)\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) and Ïƒ~Ï„,n2â€‹(Î»,un,h)\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) of [15], we take the kernel K3â€‹(x)=1516â€‹(1âˆ’x2)2â€‹ğŸ|x|â‰¤1K_{3}(x)=\frac{15}{16}(1-x^{2})^{2}\mathbf{1}_{|x|\leq 1} as specified on [15, p.Â 1964]888K3K_{3} is the best-performing kernel among those considered in [15] that satisfies the assumptions of their results (in particular, that is continuously differentiable as assumed by their main theorem). We also use the best-performing bandwidth as reported in their simulations, h=Î”n0.51h=\Delta_{n}^{0.51} and un=Î”n0.0025Bâ€‹Vu_{n}=\frac{\Delta_{n}^{0.0025}}{\sqrt{BV}}999Instead of using bipower variation for unu_{n}, the authors of [15] employed a scaled local bipower variation defined as Bâ€‹VÏ„=Ï€2â€‹(i2âˆ’i1)â€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=i1i2|Î”iâ€‹X|â€‹|Î”i+1â€‹X|,BV_{\tau}=\frac{\pi}{2(i_{2}-i_{1})\Delta_{n}}\sum_{i=i_{1}}^{i_{2}}|\Delta_{i}X||\Delta_{i+1}X|, where i1=âŒŠÏ„âˆ’hÎ”n+1âŒ‹âˆ¨1i_{1}=\left\lfloor\frac{\tau-h}{\Delta_{n}}+1\right\rfloor\vee 1 and i2=âŒŠÏ„+hÎ”n+1âŒ‹âˆ§ni_{2}=\left\lfloor\frac{\tau+h}{\Delta_{n}}+1\right\rfloor\wedge n. However, in our experiments, this choice lead to large RMSE when aggregating errors across various Ï„\tau, particularly for Y=1.2Y=1.2. In contrast, the estimators demonstrated greater stability with our proposed choice of unu_{n}.. The remaining tuning parameters Î¶â†’1\vec{\zeta}_{1}, Î¶â†’2\vec{\zeta}_{2}, Î»\lambda, pp, p1p_{1}, (p1,p2)(p_{1},p_{2}) are selected via a grid search that minimizes Râ€‹Mâ€‹Sâ€‹E^\widehat{RMSE}101010Specifically, to each point in the grid, we simulated M=100M=100 independent paths to estimate the Râ€‹Mâ€‹Sâ€‹E^\widehat{RMSE} for the associated parameter settings.. The grid for Î¶\zeta and Î»\lambda ranged from 1.1 to 1.9 with increments of 0.05, while the grid for pp spanned from 0.1 to 0.9 with increments of 0.05. For reproducibility, where applicable, we also report the auxiliary tuning parameter values found in our grid search for each considered estimator.

As in [15], we take T=1T=1 month and n=8580n=8580, roughly corresponding to a 5-minute sampling frequency (assuming 24 hours of trading). For additional comparison, we also include the results for n=42900n=42900, corresponding to roughly 1-minute frequency data in this setup. Using M=1000M=1000 iterations, we report the results in Tables 1 and 2. We consider the values Yâˆˆ{0.8,1.2,1.6,1.75}Y\in\{0.8,1.2,1.6,1.75\}, which correspond to the cases where, in principle, no debiasing is needed (Yâˆˆ{0.8,1.2}Y\in\{0.8,1.2\}), one step of debiasing is needed (Y=1.6Y=1.6), and two steps are needed (Y=1.75)(Y=1.75) to attain asymptotic efficiency according to our theory, though we may observe very different finite sample behavior.

As shown in Tables 1 and 2, the two-step debiasing estimator c~n(2)\tilde{c}_{n}^{(2)} consistently delivers the best performance, with the lowest RMSE and ARE, and generally well-controlled error. The advantage of two-step debiasing becomes especially pronounced as YY increases: While the performance of Ïƒ^n2\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{n} and Ïƒ~n2\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}_{n} deteriorates sharply, the one- and two-step debiased estimators exhibit markedly greater robustness against increased jump activity. Notably, two-step debiasing yields improvement even where it is not strictly needed for asymptotically efficient estimation (Y=0.8,1.2Y=0.8,1.2). The pattern is similar at both 5-minute and 1-minute frequencies, where the two-step debiasing method is the only one that remains stable across all considered settings, offering reductions in RMSE often by a factor of 2 to 5 relative to the considered benchmarks.

Across kernel choices for c~n(i)\tilde{c}_{n}^{(i)}, the exponential kernel systematically outperforms the uniform kernel across all values of YY and at both 1- and 5-minute sampling frequencies. This finding is consistent with the established theoretical optimality of exponential kernels in related settings where debiasing is not required [8], and more broadly underscores the advantages of using unbounded kernels in spot volatility estimation. Overall, the two-step estimator with the exponential kernel achieves the strongest and most reliable performance among all configurations considered.

4.2 Simulation with truncated stable jump component

In this section, we consider a parameter setting that more closely reflects the empirical features of financial data. We also take a truncated stable LÃ©vy process as the jump component, which is common in applications. We also study the effect of the truncation level vnv_{n}.

For this experiment, we fix a time unit of 1 year (i.e., tt is measured in years). The increments of the observed process (corresponding to an assetâ€™s log return over (tiâˆ’1,ti](t_{i-1},t_{i}]) are given by

Î”iâ€‹X\displaystyle\Delta_{i}X =Xtiâˆ’Xtiâˆ’1=âˆ«tiâˆ’1tiVsâ€‹ğ‘‘Ws+(Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ§0.005),\displaystyle=X_{t_{i}}-X_{t_{i-1}}=\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\sqrt{V_{s}}\,dW_{s}+(\Delta_{i}J\wedge 0.005),\, (55)

where JJ is a symmetric YY-stable LÃ©vy process with scale parameter 0.50.5 and VV follows the same Heston model (54) with parameter values as in [3]:

Ï=âˆ’0.5,Îº=5,Î¾=0.5,Î¸=0.16.\rho=-0.5,\quad\kappa=5,\quad\xi=0.5,\quad\theta=0.16.

In particular, we note the annualized average volatility is .16=.4\sqrt{.16}=.4, which is more realistic for financial data. Assuming 252 trading days per year, and a 6.5 hour trading day, we set Î”n=(252âˆ—6.5âˆ—12)âˆ’1\Delta_{n}=(252*6.5*12)^{-1}, corresponding to a sampling frequency of 5 minutes. We consider a time horizon of 3 months (T=14T=\frac{1}{4}), yielding a sample size of n=T/Î”n=4914n=T/\Delta_{n}=4914. In our experiments, we examine performance in the cases Y=1.6Y=1.6 and Y=1.75Y=1.75, corresponding to 1 and 2 steps of debiasing required for efficiency, and use an exponential kernel for our estimators c^nâ€‹(mn,Î”n)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\Delta_{n}), c~m,Ï„(1)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}_{m,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{1}) and c~n,Ï„(2)â€‹(mn,vn,Î¶â†’2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}). The tuning parameters are similar to the previous section, with Î¶â†’1\vec{\zeta}_{1}, Î¶â†’2\vec{\zeta}_{2}, Î»\lambda, pp, p1p_{1}, and (p1,p2)(p_{1},p_{2}) being selected via a grid search that minimizes Râ€‹Mâ€‹Sâ€‹E^\widehat{RMSE} over 100 iterations (using the same grid as described in previous section), but here we take vn=Bâ€‹Vâ€‹v0v_{n}=\sqrt{BV}v_{0}, for different v0v_{0} to assess the sensitivity of our methods to the threshold choice. We report the performance for our estimators across various threshold choices v0v_{0} in Table 3 (Y=1.6)(Y=1.6) and in Table 4 (Y=1.75)(Y=1.75) as measured by Râ€‹Mâ€‹Sâ€‹E^\widehat{RMSE}, Aâ€‹Râ€‹E^\widehat{ARE} and Râ€‹E^\widehat{RE} using M=1000M=1000 paths. In each table, we also include the performance of the estimators of [15] for comparison. We also report the auxiliary tuning parameter values found in our grid search.

As shown in Tables 3 and 4, for both Y=1.6Y=1.6 and Y=1.75Y=1.75 the two-step estimator c~n(2)\tilde{c}_{n}^{(2)} again provides the most reliable performance, delivering the lowest or near-lowest RMSE and ARE across all v0v_{0} considered. The advantage of debiasing is most pronounced at the moderate threshold choices v0=Î”n20/48=Î”n5/12v_{0}=\Delta_{n}^{20/48}=\Delta_{n}^{5/12} and v0=Î”n21/48v_{0}=\Delta_{n}^{21/48}, where the two-step estimators offer reductions in RMSE over Ïƒ^n2\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{n} and Ïƒ~n2\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{n} by roughly a factor of 2, and these improvements are observed consistently for both Y=1.6Y=1.6 and Y=1.75Y=1.75. Remarkably, the choice v0=Î”n5/12v_{0}=\Delta_{n}^{5/12} is the same as suggested by the theory for two-step debiasing in the integrated volatility case (see [3]). Broadly, these findings highlight the benefit of two-step debiasing beyond specific threshold choices, offering reliable nontrivial reductions in MSE across a variety of jump activity levels.

Appendix A Additional technical proofs

Throughout the proofs below, we make use of the following notation:

xi:=\displaystyle x_{i}:= btiâˆ’1â€‹Î”n+Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹J,x^i:=Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹J,\displaystyle b_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}+\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J,\;\;\hat{x}_{i}:=\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J,
Îµi:=\displaystyle\varepsilon_{i}:= Î”iâ€‹Xâˆ’xi=âˆ«tiâˆ’1tiÏƒtâ€‹ğ‘‘Wtâˆ’Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+âˆ«tiâˆ’1tiÏ‡tâ€‹ğ‘‘Jtâˆ’Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹J+âˆ«tiâˆ’1tibtâ€‹ğ‘‘tâˆ’btiâˆ’1â€‹Î”n.\displaystyle\Delta_{i}X-x_{i}=\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\sigma_{t}dW_{t}-\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\chi_{t}dJ_{t}-\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J+\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}b_{t}dt-b_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}. (56)

In what follows we often refer to the following standard moment estimates of the error terms (see Lemma 3 in [4]):

ğ”¼â€‹[|Îµi|p|â„±tiâˆ’1]â‰¤Câ€‹Î”n(2âˆ§p)+p2,\mathbb{E}\left[|\varepsilon_{i}|^{p}\big|\mathcal{F}_{t_{i-1}}\right]\leq C\Delta_{n}^{\frac{(2\wedge p)+p}{2}}, (57)

for any p>0p>0 and a constant CC.

A.1 Proof of Proposition 1

Similar to [3] and [4], we approximate the original process XtX_{t} by

Xtâ€²:=âˆ«0tbsâ€‹ğ‘‘s+âˆ«0tÏƒsâ€‹ğ‘‘Ws+âˆ«0tÏ‡sâ€‹ğ‘‘Jsâˆ,X_{t}^{\prime}:=\int_{0}^{t}b_{s}\,ds+\int_{0}^{t}\sigma_{s}\,dW_{s}+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}\,dJ_{s}^{\infty}, (58)

where, with Î´0âˆˆ(0,1)\delta_{0}\in(0,1) being chosen such that qâ€‹(x)>0q(x)>0 for all |x|â‰¤Î´0|x|\leq\delta_{0} and denoting the jump measure of JJ and its compensated version as NN and NÂ¯\bar{N}, respectively, the process JâˆJ^{\infty} is defined as

Jtâˆ:=(bÂ¯+âˆ«Î´0<|x|â‰¤1xâ€‹Î½â€‹(dâ€‹x))â€‹t+âˆ«0tâˆ«|x|â‰¤Î´0xâ€‹NÂ¯â€‹(dâ€‹s,dâ€‹x)+JË˜t.J_{t}^{\infty}:=\left(\bar{b}+\int_{\delta_{0}<|x|\leq 1}x\,\nu(dx)\right)t+\int_{0}^{t}\int_{|x|\leq\delta_{0}}x\,\bar{N}(ds,dx)+\breve{J}_{t}. (59)

The term JË˜t\breve{J}_{t} is a pure-jump LÃ©vy process, independent of JJ, with characteristic triplet (0,0,Î½Ë˜)(0,0,\breve{\nu}), where its LÃ©vy measure, Î½Ë˜\breve{\nu}, is given by

Î½Ë˜â€‹(dâ€‹x):=eâˆ’|x|pâ€‹(C+â€‹ğŸ(0,âˆ)â€‹(x)+Câˆ’â€‹ğŸ(âˆ’âˆ,0)â€‹(x))â€‹ğŸ|x|>Î´0â€‹|x|âˆ’1âˆ’Yâ€‹dâ€‹x,\breve{\nu}(dx):=e^{-|x|^{p}}\left(C_{+}\mathbf{1}_{(0,\infty)}(x)+C_{-}\mathbf{1}_{(-\infty,0)}(x)\right)\mathbf{1}_{|x|>\delta_{0}}|x|^{-1-Y}\,dx,

for a fixed constant p<1âˆ§Yp<1\wedge Y. Additionally, we write

Jt0:=Jtâˆ’Jtâˆ=âˆ«0tâˆ«|x|>Î´0xâ€‹Nâ€‹(dâ€‹s,dâ€‹x)âˆ’JË˜t,J_{t}^{0}:=J_{t}-J_{t}^{\infty}=\int_{0}^{t}\int_{|x|>\delta_{0}}xN(ds,dx)-\breve{J}_{t}, (60)

and note that

Xtâˆ’Xtâ€²=âˆ«0tâˆ«Î´â€‹(s,z)â€‹ğ”­â€‹(dâ€‹s,dâ€‹z)+âˆ«0tÏ‡sâ€‹ğ‘‘Js0.X_{t}-X_{t}^{\prime}=\int_{0}^{t}\int\delta(s,z)\mathfrak{p}(ds,dz)+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}^{0}.

In conclusion, the process Xâ€²X^{\prime} contains the continuous part and the jumps of the infinite variation, and Xâˆ’Xâ€²X-X^{\prime} only includes the jumps of bounded variation.

A.1.1 Proof of (14)

This expansion follows from the one obtained in [3, Lemma 4]. Indeed, the condition Y<8/5Y<8/5 stated in the hypotheses of that lemma is not used in its proof.

A.1.2 Proof of (15)

The proof of (15) follows along the lines of the proof of Lemma 2 and Lemma 5 in [3]. The main difference is that [3] has the constraint vnâ‰«Î”n32â€‹(2+Y)v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{2(2+Y)}} as well as the condition Yâ‰¤8/5Y\leq 8/5. However, these restrictions were imposed to achieve an error term of order oPâ€‹(Î”n3/2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}) in the expansion therein, while, in our case, it suffices to have an error of order oPâ€‹(Î”n54)+OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{5}{4}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y}). Under this more relaxed constraint, we will show the statement (15) holds under the entire range Yâˆˆ(0,1)âˆª(1,2)Y\in(0,1)\cup(1,2).

Note that the proof of Lemma 2 in [3] remains valid for 0<Y<10<Y<1, without relying on the condition vnâ‰«Î”n32â€‹(2+Y)v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{2(2+Y)}}. Hence, Lemma 2 holds for 0<Y<10<Y<1 under the weaker condition Î”n1/2â‰ªvnâ‰ªÎ”n1/(4âˆ’Y)\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}, which in turn implies (15). In the following, we focus on the proof for the case 1<Y<21<Y<2.

First, we show that the expansion (15) holds when XX is a sum of a Brownian motion and the tempered stable LÃ©vy process JâˆJ^{\infty} defined in (59). This fact actually follows directly from Proposition 2 in [4]. Indeed, it was shown there that for such a process the error, excluding exponentially decaying terms, is of order OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’Yâˆ’2)+OPâ€‹(Î”n2â€‹vn2âˆ’2â€‹Y)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Î´Â¯)+OPâ€‹(Î”n3/2â€‹vn1âˆ’Y/2)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\bar{\delta}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}v_{n}^{1-Y/2}). However, we observe that both Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Î´Â¯\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\bar{\delta}} and Î”n32â€‹vn1âˆ’Y/2\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{2}}v_{n}^{1-Y/2} are oPâ€‹(Î”n54)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{5}{4}}) and Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’Yâˆ’2â‰«Î”n2â€‹vn2âˆ’2â€‹Y\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2}\gg\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y} since vnâ‰ªÎ”n1/(4âˆ’Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}. Therefore, the expansion of Proposition 2 in [4] is valid for any Yâˆˆ(1,2)Y\in(1,2) with the errors being of order OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)+oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}).

As in [3], we next extend the expansion for the process Xâ€²X^{\prime} defined in (58), which broadly replaces JJ with JâˆJ^{\infty} and omits the last bounded variation Poisson term in XX. This is done in Lemma 2 in [3]. To conclude that the expansion therein holds, but with an adjusted error of order OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)+oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}), it suffices to show the terms Ri,1R_{i,1} and Ri,4R_{i,4} appearing in the proof of [3, Lemma 2] are of order oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}). We only show Ri,4=oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4)R_{i,4}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}) since the argument for Ri,1R_{i,1} is similar. It suffices to bound Di,1D_{i,1} and Di,2D_{i,2} as defined on [3, p.20]. To obtain Di,1=oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4)D_{i,1}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}), under the constraint 1<Y<21<Y<2, the analog of [3, eq.Â (B.12)] reads

Î”nâ€‹vn1âˆ’Yâ€‹Î´â‰ªÎ”n5/4â‡”Î´â‰ªÎ”n1/4â€‹vnYâˆ’1.\displaystyle\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{1-Y}\delta\ll\Delta_{n}^{5/4}\quad\iff\quad\delta\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/4}v_{n}^{Y-1}. (61)

To obtain Di,2=oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4)D_{i,2}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}) for 1<Y<21<Y<2, it suffices to bound the terms ğ’±i,2\mathcal{V}_{i,2} and ğ’±i,3\mathcal{V}_{i,3} defined on [3, p.Â 21]. Following the same argument leading to [3, eq.Â (B.13)], to obtain ğ’±i,1=oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4),\mathcal{V}_{i,1}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}), we require, for arbitrarily small sâ€²,sâ€²â€²>0s^{\prime},s^{\prime\prime}>0,

Î”n5/2âˆ’sâ€²â€‹vn1âˆ’Yâˆ’sâ€²â€²â€‹Î´âˆ’1â‰ªÎ”n5/4â‡”Î´â‰«Î”n5/4âˆ’sâ€²â€‹vn1âˆ’Yâˆ’sâ€²â€².\displaystyle\Delta_{n}^{5/2-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}\delta^{-1}\ll\Delta_{n}^{5/4}\quad\iff\quad\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{5/4-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}. (62)

The conditions (61) and (62) are consistent for any 1<Y<21<Y<2, since

Î”n5/4âˆ’sâ€²â€‹vn1âˆ’Yâˆ’sâ€²â€²â‰ªÎ”n1/4â€‹vnYâˆ’1â‡”Î”n1âˆ’sâ€²2â€‹Yâˆ’2+sâ€²â€²â‰ªvn,\Delta_{n}^{5/4-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/4}v_{n}^{Y-1}\Leftrightarrow\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1-s^{\prime}}{2Y-2+s^{\prime\prime}}}\ll v_{n},

which holds for sufficiently small sâ€²,sâ€²â€²s^{\prime},s^{\prime\prime} under our condition Î”n12âˆ’sâ‰ªvn\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}-s}\ll v_{n}. Finally, for the term ğ’±i,3,\mathcal{V}_{i,3}, since vnâ‰ªÎ”n14âˆ’Yv_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}}, the condition Î´â‰«Î”n12â€‹vnY2\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}}v_{n}^{\frac{Y}{2}} imposed at the end of the proof of [3, Lemma 2] is consistent with (61). The condition Î´â‰«Î”n12â€‹vnY2\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}}v_{n}^{\frac{Y}{2}} enables us to apply [4, Lemma 4] and conclude that ğ”¼â€‹(Vi,3)=Oâ€‹(Î”n2â€‹vn2âˆ’2â€‹Y)\mathbb{E}(V_{i,3})=O(\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y}), which is obviously also Oâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’Yâˆ’2)O(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2}), as desired.

To conclude the proof, with the updated error OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)+oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}) and the more general process XX, it remains to establish an analog of Lemma 5 in [3], which allows us to add the last bounded variation term to XX and go from JâˆJ^{\infty} to the more general tempered stable LÃ©vy process JJ. This is detailed in Section A.1.4 below.

A.1.3 Proof of (16)

We first note that the expansion (16) holds when XX is a sum of a Brownian motion and the independent tempered stable LÃ©vy process JâˆJ^{\infty} on account of [4, Proposition 2], which implies that that the error terms in (16) are OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’Yâˆ’2)+OPâ€‹(Î”n2â€‹vn2âˆ’2â€‹Y)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Î´Â¯)+OPâ€‹(Î”n3/2â€‹vn1âˆ’Y/2)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\bar{\delta}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}v_{n}^{1-Y/2}). As with the proof of (15), we can similarly check that OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y}) and oPâ€‹(Î”n34â€‹vn4âˆ’Y2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}) dominate the higher order terms Î”n2â€‹vn2âˆ’2â€‹Y\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y}, Î”n32â€‹vn1âˆ’Y2\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{2}}v_{n}^{1-\frac{Y}{2}} and Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Î´Â¯\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\bar{\delta}} therein.

Next, similarly to [3, Lemma 3], we argue that the expansion (16) holds for the process Xâ€²X^{\prime} defined in (58). Indeed, following the proof of [3, Lemma 3], it suffices to obtain bounds for the terms ğ’ŸÂ¯i,1\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,1} and ğ’ŸÂ¯i,2\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,2} on [3, p.22]. First to show ğ’ŸÂ¯i,1=oPâ€‹(Î”n34â€‹vn4âˆ’Y2)\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,1}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}), we arrive at the constraint analogous to [3, eq.Â (B.17)]:

Î”nâ€‹vn1âˆ’Yâ€‹Î´â‰ªÎ”n34â€‹vn4âˆ’Y2â‡”Î´â‰ªÎ”nâˆ’14â€‹vn1+Y2.\displaystyle\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{1-Y}\delta\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}\quad\iff\quad\delta\ll\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{4}}v_{n}^{1+\frac{Y}{2}}. (63)

Similarly, to obtain ğ’ŸÂ¯i,2=oPâ€‹(Î”n34â€‹vn4âˆ’Y2)+OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’Yâˆ’2)\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,2}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2}), we first recall that (see [3, eq.Â (B.19)]), under the constraint Î´â‰«Î”n1/2â€‹vnY/2\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{1/2}v_{n}^{Y/2},

ğ’ŸÂ¯i,2=OPâ€‹(Î”n5/2âˆ’sâ€²â€‹vn1âˆ’Yâˆ’sâ€²â€²â€‹Î´âˆ’1)+OPâ€‹(Î”2â€‹vn2âˆ’2â€‹Y).\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,2}=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/2-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}\delta^{-1})+O_{P}(\Delta^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y}).

The second term above is OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’Yâˆ’2)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2}) because vnâ‰ªÎ”n1/(4âˆ’Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}. For the first term above to be oPâ€‹(Î”n34â€‹vn4âˆ’Y2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}), we need:

Î”n5/2âˆ’sâ€²â€‹vn1âˆ’Yâˆ’sâ€²â€²â€‹Î´âˆ’1â‰ªÎ”n34â€‹vn4âˆ’Y2â‡”Î”n74âˆ’sâ€²â€‹vnâˆ’1âˆ’Y2âˆ’sâ€²â€²â‰ªÎ´,\displaystyle\Delta_{n}^{5/2-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}\delta^{-1}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}\quad\iff\quad\Delta_{n}^{\frac{7}{4}-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{-1-\frac{Y}{2}-s^{\prime\prime}}\ll\delta, (64)

which is compatible with (63) if Î”n74â€‹vnâˆ’1âˆ’Y2â‰ªÎ”nâˆ’14â€‹vn1+Y2\Delta_{n}^{\frac{7}{4}}v_{n}^{-1-\frac{Y}{2}}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{4}}v_{n}^{1+\frac{Y}{2}} or, equivalently, Î”n22+Yâ‰ªvn\Delta_{n}^{\frac{2}{2+Y}}\ll v_{n}. The latter obviously holds for all 0<Y<20<Y<2 since vnâ‰«Î”n12v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}}. On the other hand, (63) is also compatible with the constraint Î´â‰«Î”n1/2â€‹vnY/2\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{1/2}v_{n}^{Y/2} required for [3, eq.Â (B.19)] since Î”n1/2â‰ªvn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}. The remaining part of the proof is the same as Lemma 3 in [3]. To carry the expansion of [3, Lemma 3], with the updated error OPâ€‹(Î”n3â€‹vnâˆ’2âˆ’Y)+oPâ€‹(Î”n34â€‹vn4âˆ’Y2)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}), to the most general process XX, it remains to establish an appropriate analog of Lemma 5 in [3]. This is detailed in Section A.1.4 below.

A.1.4 Analog of Lemma 5 in [3]

With r=r0âˆˆ(0,Yâˆ§1)r=r_{0}\in(0,Y\wedge 1), Lemma 5 in [3] states that for any Î±â‰¥1\alpha\geq 1,

|(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}âˆ’(Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn}|\displaystyle|(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}-(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}|
=OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Î±â€‹r0)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Yâˆ’1+Î±).\displaystyle\quad=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y-1+\alpha}). (65)

The above equation still holds under the hypotheses of Proposition 1. To establish (14), it is further required that the above terms are oPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}), which can be ensured by choosing Î±\alpha close to 1 from above, since r0<Yr_{0}<Y, Î”nâ€‹vnâˆ’r1â€‹Î±â‰ªÎ”nâ€‹vnâˆ’2â‰ª1\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-r_{1}\alpha}\ll\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-2}\ll 1 under our condition r0âˆˆ[0,Yâˆ§1)r_{0}\in[0,Y\wedge 1).

For (15) and (16), the corresponding requirements for the errors in (65) are oPâ€‹(Î”n5/4)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}) and oPâ€‹(Î”n3/4â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}), respectively. Since Î”n3/4â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2â‰ªÎ”n5/4\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}\ll\Delta_{n}^{5/4} under vnâ‰ªÎ”n1/(4âˆ’Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}, it suffices to establish that the terms are oPâ€‹(Î”n3/4â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}), which occurs if the following hold:

  1. 1.

    Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Î±â€‹r0â‰ªÎ”n3/4â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\alpha r_{0}}\ll\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}, which holds if Î±<(Y+1)/(2â€‹r0)\alpha<(Y+1)/(2r_{0}). This is obtained by observing Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Î±â€‹r0â‰ªÎ”n3/4â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2â‡”Î”nâ‰ªvn4â€‹Î±â€‹r0âˆ’2â€‹Y\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\alpha r_{0}}\ll\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}\Leftrightarrow\Delta_{n}\ll v_{n}^{4\alpha r_{0}-2Y} and, since we required Î”n1/2â‰ªvn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}, we only need to impose that vn2â‰ªvn4â€‹Î±â€‹r0âˆ’2â€‹Yv_{n}^{2}\ll v_{n}^{4\alpha r_{0}-2Y}, which is satisfied if Î±<(Y+1)/(2â€‹r0)\alpha<(Y+1)/(2r_{0}).

  2. 2.

    Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Yâˆ’1+Î±â‰ªÎ”n3/4â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y-1+\alpha}\ll\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2} if Î±>1/2+Y/2\alpha>1/2+Y/2. This is obtained by observing Î”nâ€‹vn2âˆ’Yâˆ’1+Î±â‰ªÎ”n3/4â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/2â‡”Î”n1/(2â€‹Y+4âˆ’4â€‹Î±)â‰ªvn\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y-1+\alpha}\ll\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}\Leftrightarrow\Delta_{n}^{1/(2Y+4-4\alpha)}\ll v_{n} and comparing Î”n1/(2â€‹Y+4âˆ’4â€‹Î±)â‰ªÎ”n1/2\Delta_{n}^{1/(2Y+4-4\alpha)}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2}.

In conclusion, we need to pick Î±\alpha such that

1+Y2<Î±<1+Y2â€‹r0,\frac{1+Y}{2}<\alpha<\frac{1+Y}{2r_{0}},

which is always possible given r0âˆˆ[0,1)r_{0}\in[0,1).

A.1.5 Proof of (17)

As with the proofs of (15) and (16), we proceed in two steps: first we show (17) for the process Xâ€²X^{\prime} defined in (58) and then, we show the analog of Lemma 5 in [3]; i.e., we show that, for any real number p>1p>1,

|(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}âˆ’(Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn}|=OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y).|(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}-(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}|=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). (66)

Note that (66) allows non-integer moment and does not directly follow from Lemma 5 in [3].

For simplicity, we re-use the notation in (A), except with JtâˆJ_{t}^{\infty} in place of JtJ_{t}. To prove (17), we need to show that, for any p>1p>1, the following two estimates hold:

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vn}|2â€‹p=OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y),\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}), (67)

and

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|(Î”iâ€‹X)â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}|2â€‹pâˆ’ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vn}|2â€‹p=OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y).\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|(\Delta_{i}X)\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}-\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). (68)

We begin with (67) and proceed along the lines of Proposition 3 in [4]. It suffices to show

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|â‰¤vn})=OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y).\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). (69)

Note that

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|â‰¤vn})\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(\big|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}\big|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)
â‰²ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W|2â€‹p+ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|â‰¤vn}),\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|^{2p}+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big),

and, by self-similarity, ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W|2â€‹p=OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|^{2p}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p}). Thus, to show (69), it suffices that

An:=ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|â‰¤vn})â‰²Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y+Î”np.A_{n}:=\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)\lesssim\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{p}.

Note that ğŸ{|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|â‰¤vn}â‰¤ğŸ|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W|â‰¤vnâ€‹ğŸ{|Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|â‰¤2â€‹vn}+ğŸ|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W|>vn\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\leq\mathbf{1}_{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}}. Then we may further write

An\displaystyle A_{n} â‰¤ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|â‰¤2â€‹vn})+ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|â‰¤vn}â‹…ğŸ|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W|>vn)\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}\big)+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\cdot\mathbf{1}_{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}}\big)
=:V1+V2.\displaystyle=:V_{1}+V_{2}.

For V1V_{1}, by (B.38) in [4], we obtain that

V1â‰²Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y+Î”np.\displaystyle V_{1}\lesssim\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{p}. (70)

For V2V_{2}, let KK be the smallest positive integer such that K>pK>p. And further assume Ïƒtiâˆ’1â‰ 0\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\neq 0, otherwise V2=0V_{2}=0. By HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality and (B.37) in [4], we have

V2\displaystyle V_{2} â‰¤ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|2â€‹Kâ€‹ğŸ{|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jâˆ|â‰¤vn})pKâ€‹Pâ€‹(|Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W|>vn)Kâˆ’pK\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2K}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)^{\frac{p}{K}}P\big(|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}\big)^{\frac{K-p}{K}}
â‰²(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹Kâˆ’Y+Î”n2â€‹vn2â€‹Kâˆ’Yâˆ’2+Î”n2â€‹Kâˆ’Y/2)pKâ€‹expâ¡(âˆ’Kâˆ’p2â€‹Kâ€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹(Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vn2)),\displaystyle\lesssim(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2K-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2K-Y-2}+\Delta_{n}^{2K-Y/2})^{\frac{p}{K}}\exp\Big(-\frac{K-p}{2K{\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}}}(\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{2})\Big), (71)

which vanishes faster than any power of Î”n\Delta_{n} given Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vn2â‰«Î”nâˆ’2â€‹s\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{2}\gg{\Delta_{n}^{-2s}} and hence V2=oPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)V_{2}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). Combining (70) and (71) yields (69).

Now we proceed to establish (68). Note that for any q>1q>1 and real numbers a,ba,b, we have111111Indeed, for some Î¸âˆˆ(0,1)\theta\in(0,1), ||b|qâˆ’|a|q|=qâ€‹||b|âˆ’|a||â€‹|(Î¸â€‹|a|+(1âˆ’Î¸)â€‹|b|)|qâˆ’1â‰¤qâ€‹||b|âˆ’|a||â€‹(|a|qâˆ’1+|b|qâˆ’1)||b|^{q}-|a|^{q}|=q||b|-|a|||(\theta|a|+(1-\theta)|b|)|^{q-1}\leq q||b|-|a||(|a|^{q-1}+|b|^{q-1}) because clearly Î¸â€‹|a|+(1âˆ’Î¸)â€‹|b|â‰¤maxâ¡{|a|,|b|}\theta|a|+(1-\theta)|b|\leq\max\{|a|,|b|\}.

||a|qâˆ’|b|q|â‰¤qâ€‹||a|âˆ’|b||â€‹(|a|qâˆ’1+|b|qâˆ’1).\displaystyle\big||a|^{q}-|b|^{q}\big|\leq q\big||a|-|b|\big|\big(|a|^{q-1}+|b|^{q-1}\big). (72)

We utilize the inequality (72) to bound (68) by taking q=2â€‹pq=2p, a=(Î”iâ€‹X)â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}a=(\Delta_{i}X)\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}, and b=xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vn}b=x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}. Also, recalling that Î”iâ€‹X=xi+Îµi\Delta_{i}X=x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}, we have

||a|âˆ’|b||â‰¤|aâˆ’b|â‰¤|Îµiâ€‹|ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}+|â€‹xi|â€‹(ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn<|xi|}+ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vn<|xi+Îµi|}).\big||a|-|b|\big|\leq|a-b|\leq|\varepsilon_{i}|\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}+|x_{i}|(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}}).

Using the two inequalities above together with |x+Îµ|2â€‹pâˆ’1â‰¤22â€‹pâˆ’2â€‹(|x|2â€‹pâˆ’1+|Îµ|2â€‹pâˆ’2)|x+\varepsilon|^{2p-1}\leq 2^{2p-2}(|x|^{2p-1}+|\varepsilon|^{2p-2}), we obtain:

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|(Î”iâ€‹X)â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}|2â€‹pâˆ’ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vn}|2â€‹p\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|(\Delta_{i}X)\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}-\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}
â‰²ğ”¼iâˆ’1{[|ÎµiğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}|+|xi|(ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn<|xi|}+ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vn<|xi+Îµi|})]\displaystyle\lesssim\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\Big\{\big[|\varepsilon_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|+|x_{i}|(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}})\big]
â‹…[|xi+Îµi|2â€‹pâˆ’1ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}+|xi|2â€‹pâˆ’1ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vn}]}\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\cdot\big[{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|}^{2p-1}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}+{|x_{i}|}^{2p-1}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big]\Big\}
â‰²ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Îµi2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}|+ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Îµiâ€‹xi2â€‹pâˆ’1â€‹(ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}+ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn,|xi|â‰¤vn})|\displaystyle\lesssim\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\varepsilon_{i}^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|\varepsilon_{i}x_{i}^{2p-1}(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n},|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}})\big|
+ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xi2â€‹pâ€‹(ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn<|xi|}+ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vnâ‰¤|xi+Îµi|})â€‹(ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}+ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vn})|\displaystyle\quad+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|x_{i}^{2p}(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}})(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}})\big|
=ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Îµi2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}|+ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Îµiâ€‹xi2â€‹pâˆ’1â€‹(ğŸ|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn<|xi|+ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn,|xi|â‰¤vn})|\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\varepsilon_{i}^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|\varepsilon_{i}x_{i}^{2p-1}(\mathbf{1}_{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n},|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}})\big|
+ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xi2â€‹pâ€‹(ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn<|xi|}+ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vnâ‰¤|xi+Îµi|})|\displaystyle\quad+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|x_{i}^{2p}(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}})\big|
=:Ri,1+Ri,2+Ri,3.\displaystyle=:R_{i,1}+R_{i,2}+R_{i,3}. (73)

By (57), we obtain Ri,1=OPâ€‹(Î”n1+p)=oPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)R_{i,1}=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{1+p})=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}) given Î”n1/2â‰ªvn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n} and Y>0Y>0. Now we analyze Ri,3R_{i,3}. For ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xi|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vnâ‰¤|xi+Îµi|}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}} we can directly apply (67) and consequently ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xi|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤vnâ‰¤|xi+Îµi|}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}} is of order OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y){O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})}. For the remaining term in Ri,3R_{i,3}, we consider the following decomposition:

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vnâ‰¤|xi|}|2â€‹p\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}|\}}|^{2p} â‰¤ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vnâ‰¤|xi|}â‹…ğŸ{|Îµi|â‰¤|vn|}|2â€‹p+ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vnâ‰¤|xi|}â‹…ğŸ{|Îµi|>|vn|}|2â€‹p\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}|\}}\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq|v_{n}|\}}|^{2p}+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}|\}}\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>|v_{n}|\}}|^{2p}
=:D~i,1+D~i,2.\displaystyle=:\tilde{D}_{i,1}+\tilde{D}_{i,2}.

Note that |xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} and |Îµi|â‰¤|vn||\varepsilon_{i}|\leq|v_{n}| implies |xi|â‰¤2â€‹vn|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n} and, we can again, simply apply (67) to obtain D~i,1â‰²Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y+Î”np\tilde{D}_{i,1}\lesssim\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{p}. Regarding D~i,2\tilde{D}_{i,2}, for some q>1q>1, HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality yields

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vnâ‰¤|xi|}â‹…ğŸ{|Îµi|>|2â€‹vn|}|2â€‹pâ‰¤(ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}|2â€‹pâ€‹q)1/qâ€‹Pâ€‹(|Îµi|>|2â€‹vn|)(qâˆ’1)/q,\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}|\}}\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>|2v_{n}|\}}|^{2p}\leq\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2pq}\big)^{1/q}P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>|2v_{n}|)^{(q-1)/q},

which is of order oPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}) by taking qq such that pâ€‹qpq is integer, as ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xiâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}|2â€‹pâ€‹q\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2pq} is finite by (14), while Pâ€‹(|Îµi|>|2â€‹vn|)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>|2v_{n}|) vanishes faster than any power of Î”n\Delta_{n} by (57) given that Î”nÎ²â‰ªvn\Delta_{n}^{\beta}\ll v_{n} with Î²<12\beta<\frac{1}{2}. Combining D~i,1\tilde{D}_{i,1} and D~i,2\tilde{D}_{i,2}, we obtain Ri,3=OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)R_{i,3}=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}).

Lastly, we turn to Ri,2R_{i,2} in (73). By HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality,

Ri,2\displaystyle R_{i,2} â‰¤(ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Îµi|2â€‹p)12â€‹pâ€‹(ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xi|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn<|xi|)2â€‹pâˆ’12â€‹p+(ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Îµi|2â€‹p)12â€‹pâ€‹(ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|xi|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn,|xi|â‰¤vn})2â€‹pâˆ’12â€‹p\displaystyle\leq\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\varepsilon_{i}|^{2p}\big)^{\frac{1}{2p}}\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|}\big)^{\frac{2p-1}{2p}}+\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\varepsilon_{i}|^{2p}\big)^{\frac{1}{2p}}\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n},|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)^{\frac{2p-1}{2p}}
â‰²Î”n1+p2â€‹pâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)2â€‹pâˆ’12â€‹p+Î”n1+p2â€‹pâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)2â€‹pâˆ’12â€‹p,\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1+p}{2p}}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})^{\frac{2p-1}{2p}}+\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1+p}{2p}}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})^{\frac{2p-1}{2p}},

where the second line follows from (57), (67), and the bound we obtained for D~i,2\tilde{D}_{i,2} above. We can then conclude that Ri,2=oPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)R_{i,2}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}) as Î”n1+p=oPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)\Delta_{n}^{1+p}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}).

Combining the results for Ri,1R_{i,1}, Ri,2R_{i,2}, and Ri,3R_{i,3}, we establish (68) and conclude the proof of (17) for Xtâ€²X_{t}^{\prime}. More specifically, we have obtained

ğ”¼â€‹(|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}|â„±iâˆ’1)=OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)+OPâ€‹(Cp,tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y).\mathbb{E}\big(|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2{p}}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(C_{{p},t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2{p}-Y}). (74)

Now we will show (66). Following the idea of Lemma 5 in [3], for any p>1p>1, let

D2â€‹p:=|(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}âˆ’(Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn}|.D_{2p}:=\left|(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}-(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}\right|.

Denote Vt=Xtâˆ’Xtâ€²V_{t}=X_{t}-X_{t}^{\prime}, where recalling J0J^{0} as defined in (60),

Vt:=âˆ«0tâˆ«Î´(s,z)ğ”­(ds,dz)+âˆ«0tÏ‡sdJs0=:Yt+âˆ«0tÏ‡sdJs0.V_{t}:=\int_{0}^{t}\int\delta(s,z)\mathfrak{p}(ds,dz)+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}^{0}=:Y_{t}+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}^{0}.

For any fixed pâ‰¥1p\geq 1, by decomposing the indicator ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}} and ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}, we can obtain

D2â€‹p\displaystyle D_{2p} =|(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹pâˆ’(Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²)2â€‹p|â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn,|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn}\displaystyle=\left|(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}-(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\right|\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}
+(Î”iâ€‹X)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn,|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|>vn}\displaystyle\quad+(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|>v_{n}\}}
+(Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|>vn,|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn}\displaystyle\quad+(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|>v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}
=:T1+T2+T3.\displaystyle=:T_{1}+T_{2}+T_{3}.

We start with T1T_{1}. By Taylor expansion of (xâ€²+v)2â€‹p(x^{\prime}+v)^{2p} at v=0v=0, we obtain

|(xâ€²+v)2â€‹pâˆ’(xâ€²)2â€‹p|â‰¤Kâ€‹|v|â€‹(|xâ€²|2â€‹pâˆ’1+|v|2â€‹pâˆ’1),|(x^{\prime}+v)^{2p}-(x^{\prime})^{2p}|\leq K|v|\left(|x^{\prime}|^{2p-1}+|v|^{2p-1}\right),

which applied to T1T_{1} yields

T1â‰¤Kâ€‹(|Î”iâ€‹V|2â€‹p+|Î”iâ€‹V|â€‹|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|2â€‹pâˆ’1)â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn,|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn}.T_{1}\leq K\left(|\Delta_{i}V|^{2p}+|\Delta_{i}V||\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p-1}\right)\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}. (75)

We first bound Î”iâ€‹V\Delta_{i}V. By Corollary 2.1.9 in [10], for each lâ‰¥1l\geq 1 and some constant K>0K>0, we have:

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Î”iâ€‹Yvnâˆ§1|l)â‰¤Kâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vnâˆ’r0.\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left(\left|\frac{\Delta_{i}Y}{v_{n}}\wedge 1\right|^{l}\right)\leq K\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-r_{0}}. (76)

On the other hand, since J0J^{0} is compound Poisson, if we let N0â€‹(dâ€‹s,dâ€‹x)N^{0}(ds,dx) be its jump measure, for some K>0K>0, we have

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|1vnâ€‹âˆ«tiâˆ’1tiÏ‡sâ€‹ğ‘‘Js0âˆ§1|p)â‰¤â„™â€‹(N0â€‹([tiâˆ’1,ti],â„)>0)â‰¤Kâ€‹Î”n.\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left(\left|\frac{1}{v_{n}}\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}^{0}\wedge 1\right|^{p}\right)\leq\mathbb{P}(N^{0}([t_{i-1},t_{i}],\mathbb{R})>0)\leq K\Delta_{n}.

Together with (76), we obtain

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Î”iâ€‹V|lâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹V|â‰¤vn})â‰¤Kâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vnlâˆ’r0.\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left(|\Delta_{i}V|^{l}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}V|\leq v_{n}\}}\right)\leq K\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{l-r_{0}}.

Since |x+v|â‰¤vn|x+v|\leq v_{n} and |x|â‰¤vn|x|\leq v_{n} imply |v|â‰¤2â€‹vn|v|\leq 2v_{n}, applying the above inequality to T1T_{1} we get:

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹T1â‰¤Kâ€‹(ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹V|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹V|â‰¤2â€‹vn}]+vn2â€‹pâˆ’1â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹V|â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹V|â‰¤2â€‹vn}])â‰¤Kâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’r0.\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{1}\leq K\left(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\Delta_{i}V|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}V|\leq 2v_{n}\}}]+v_{n}^{2p-1}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\Delta_{i}V|\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}V|\leq 2v_{n}\}}]\right)\leq K\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}. (77)

Now we move to T2T_{2}. For some Î±â‰¥1\alpha\geq 1 to be later specified, we may decompose T2T_{2} as follows:

T2=|Î”iX|2â€‹pğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn,|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|>vn+vnÎ±}+|Î”iX|2â€‹pğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn<|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn+vnÎ±}=:T2â€²+T2â€²â€²T_{2}=|\Delta_{i}X|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|>v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}+|\Delta_{i}X|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}<|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}=:T_{2}^{\prime}+T_{2}^{\prime\prime} (78)

Notice that |xâ€²+v|â‰¤vn|x^{\prime}+v|\leq v_{n} and |xâ€²|>vn+vnÎ±|x^{\prime}|>v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha} implies |v|>vnÎ±|v|>v_{n}^{\alpha}. For T2â€²T_{2}^{\prime} we obtain the bound

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹T2â€²\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{2}^{\prime} â‰¤vn2â€‹pâ€‹â„™iâˆ’1â€‹(|Î”iâ€‹V|>vnÎ±,|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|>vn+vnÎ±)\displaystyle\leq v_{n}^{2p}\mathbb{P}_{i-1}(|\Delta_{i}V|>v_{n}^{\alpha},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|>v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha})
â‰¤Kâ€‹vn2â€‹pâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vnâˆ’Î±â€‹r0),\displaystyle\leq Kv_{n}^{2p}\left(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-\alpha r_{0}}\right), (79)

which follows from the bound â„™iâˆ’1â€‹(|Î”iâ€‹V|>u)â‰¤ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(|Î”iâ€‹Vuâˆ§1|l)â‰¤Kâ€‹Î”nâ€‹uâˆ’r0.\mathbb{P}_{i-1}(|\Delta_{i}V|>u)\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left(\left|\frac{\Delta_{i}V}{u}\wedge 1\right|^{l}\right)\leq K\Delta_{n}u^{-r_{0}}. For T2â€²â€²T_{2}^{\prime\prime}, notice that |xâ€²+v|â‰¤vn|x^{\prime}+v|\leq v_{n} and |xâ€²|â‰¤vn+vnÎ±|x^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha} implies |v|â‰¤2â€‹vn+vnÎ±|v|\leq 2v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}. We have:

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹T2â€²â€²\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{2}^{\prime\prime} =ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹X|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn<|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn+vnÎ±}]\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}X|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}<|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}\right]
â‰¤Kâ€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|2â€‹p+|Î”iâ€‹V|2â€‹p]â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn<|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn+vnÎ±}\displaystyle\leq K\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p}+|\Delta_{i}V|^{2p}\right]\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}<|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}
â‰¤ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn+vnÎ±}+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’r0).\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}). (80)

Since Î±â‰¥1\alpha\geq 1, by (74), we obtain

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn+vnÎ±}=OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y),\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}),

which combined with (79) implies

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹T2=OPâ€‹(Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)+OPâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Î±â€‹r0).\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{2}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}}).

Lastly for T3T_{3}, similarly we may write

T3=(Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|>vn,|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vnâˆ’vnÎ±}+(Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{vnâˆ’vnÎ±<|Î”iâ€‹Xâ€²|â‰¤vn}=T3â€²+T3â€²â€².T_{3}=(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|>v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}-v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}+(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}-v_{n}^{\alpha}<|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}=T_{3}^{\prime}+T_{3}^{\prime\prime}.

Since |xâ€²+v|>vn|x^{\prime}+v|>v_{n} and |xâ€²|â‰¤vnâˆ’vnÎ±|x^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}-v_{n}^{\alpha} imply |v|>vnÎ±|v|>v_{n}^{\alpha}, the same arguments as for T2â€²,T2â€²â€²T_{2}^{\prime},T_{2}^{\prime\prime} apply to T3â€²,T3â€²â€²T_{3}^{\prime},T_{3}^{\prime\prime}. In conclusion, we have the following bound

ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹T1+ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹T2+ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹T3â‰²Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’r0+Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Î±â€‹r0+Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np+Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y.\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{1}+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{2}+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{3}\ \lesssim\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}}+\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}. (81)

To show (66), it suffices to show

Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’r0+Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Î±â€‹r0â‰²Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹Î”np+Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y.\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}}\lesssim\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}.

Indeed, notice that râˆˆ(0,Yâˆ§1)r\in(0,Y\wedge 1). It follows that Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’r0=oâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}=o(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). Thus, if we take Î±=Y2+Y2â€‹r\alpha=\frac{Y}{2}+\frac{Y}{2r}, we obtain Î±â€‹r<Y\alpha r<Y, and Since Y<2Y<2, we have

Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Î±â€‹r0=oâ€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y),\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}}=o(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}),

which concludes the proof.

A.2 Proofs of some technical identities in Theorem 1

In view of (17) and Lemma 5 in [3], in the following, we assume that the discontinuous part of XX is comprosed only of LÃ©vy-driven term of infinite variation and may omit the jumps of finite variation. Specifically, we may assume that XX takes the form:

Xt=âˆ«0tbsâ€‹ğ‘‘s+âˆ«0tÏƒsâ€‹ğ‘‘Ws+âˆ«0tÏ‡sâ€‹ğ‘‘Js.X_{t}=\int_{0}^{t}b_{s}ds+\int_{0}^{t}\sigma_{s}dW_{s}+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}.
Proof of (32).

As in [3], the key idea is to discretize the integrals involved in YiY_{i} as in (A). We treat each term in the expansion Î”iâ€‹X2=(xi+Îµi)2=xi2+2â€‹xiâ€‹Îµi+Îµi2\Delta_{i}X^{2}=(x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i})^{2}=x_{i}^{2}+2x_{i}\varepsilon_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}^{2} separately. For the third term Îµi2\varepsilon_{i}^{2}, by Cauchy-Schwarz, we obtain

mn|âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”n(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)ğ”¼iâˆ’1Îµi2ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}(Î”iM))|2\displaystyle m_{n}\Big|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\varepsilon_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\big)\Big|^{2}
â‰¤mnâ€‹|âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Îµi4)1/2â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M2)1/2|2\displaystyle\quad\leq m_{n}\Big|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\varepsilon_{i}^{4})^{1/2}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})^{1/2}\Big|^{2}
â‰¤mnâ€‹(âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Îµi4))â€‹(âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M2))\displaystyle\quad\leq m_{n}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\varepsilon_{i}^{4})\Big)\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})\Big)
â‰¤mnâ€‹Î”nâˆ’1â€‹OPâ€‹(Î”n3)â€‹OPâ€‹(1mnâ€‹Î”n)=OPâ€‹(Î”n)â†’0,\displaystyle\quad\leq m_{n}\Delta_{n}^{-1}O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3})O_{P}\big(\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\big)=O_{P}(\Delta_{n})\rightarrow 0, (82)

where the second inequality follows from Cauchy-Schwarz concerning the summation and the last inequality is due to (57) and

ğ”¼â€‹(âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M2))â‰²1mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M2)=OPâ€‹(1mnâ€‹Î”n),\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})\big)\lesssim\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})=O_{P}\big(\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\big), (83)

which follows from the boundedness of Kâ€‹(â‹…)K(\cdot) and the fact that MM is square integrable.

For the term 2â€‹xiâ€‹Îµi2x_{i}\varepsilon_{i}, when |Îµi|>vn|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}, since Î”n1/2/vnâ‰ªÎ”n1/2âˆ’Î²â‰ª1\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2-\beta}\ll 1, we can use Markovâ€™s inequality to conclude that

Pâ€‹(|Îµi|>vn)â‰¤Kâ€‹Î”n1+(1/2âˆ’Î²)â€‹r,P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n})\leq K\Delta_{n}^{1+(1/2-\beta)r},

for all r>Yr>Y according to (57). By taking large enough rr and applying HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality, for some q1,q2,q3>1q_{1},q_{2},q_{3}>1 and âˆ‘i=131/qi=1/2\sum_{i=1}^{3}1/q_{i}=1/2, as ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|xi|q1]\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|x_{i}|^{q_{1}}] and ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Îµi|q2]\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\varepsilon_{i}|^{q_{2}}] is finite, we can show that

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|xiâ€‹Îµi|â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹X|â‰¤vn}â€‹ğŸ{|Îµi|>vn}â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M)]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|x_{i}\varepsilon_{i}|\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\right]
â‰¤mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|xi|q1]1/q1â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Îµi|q2]1/q2â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M2)1/2â€‹Piâˆ’1â€‹(|Îµi|>vn)1/q3\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|x_{i}|^{q_{1}}]^{1/q_{1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\varepsilon_{i}|^{q_{2}}]^{1/q_{2}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})^{1/2}P_{i-1}(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n})^{1/{q_{3}}}
â‰¤mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|xi|q1]1/q1â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Îµi|q2]1/q2â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M2)1/2â€‹Î”n1/q3+(1/2âˆ’Î²)â€‹r/q3\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|x_{i}|^{q_{1}}]^{1/q_{1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\varepsilon_{i}|^{q_{2}}]^{1/q_{2}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/q_{3}+(1/2-\beta)r/q_{3}}
=oPâ€‹(1).\displaystyle\quad=o_{P}(1). (84)

When |Îµi|â‰¤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}, note |Î”iâ€‹X|=|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn|\Delta_{i}X|=|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} implies that |xi|â‰¤2â€‹vn|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n}. Then by applying Cauchy-Schwarz twice, we obtain:

mnâ€‹|âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Îµiâ€‹xi|â€‹ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤2â€‹vn}â€‹ğŸ{|Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹M|]|2\displaystyle m_{n}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\varepsilon_{i}x_{i}|\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}M|\right]\right|^{2}
â‰¤mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[Îµi2â€‹xi2â€‹ğŸ{|xi|â‰¤2â€‹vn}]â€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹M)2]\displaystyle\leq m_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\varepsilon_{i}^{2}x_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}\right]\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]
â‰¤mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹OPâ€‹(Î”n3/2)â€‹OPâ€‹(Î”n)â€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹M)2]\displaystyle\leq m_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2})O_{P}(\Delta_{n})\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]
=mnâ€‹OPâ€‹(Î”n3/2)â€‹OPâ€‹(1mnâ€‹Î”n)=OPâ€‹(Î”n1/2)â†’ğ‘ƒ0,\displaystyle=m_{n}O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2})O_{P}\big(\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\big)=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{1/2})\xrightarrow{P}0, (85)

where in the second inequality we used Proposition 1 and (57), and in the last line, we used (83). All that remains is the term xi2x_{i}^{2}. Next, we want to show that

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[xi2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M)]â†’ğ‘ƒ0.\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[x_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\right]\xrightarrow{P}0. (86)

Firstly we start with replacing xix_{i} with btiâˆ’1â€‹Î”nb_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n} in (86) and arbitrary MM. By the boundness of btb_{t}, KK and Cauchy-Schwarz, it follows that

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[btiâˆ’12â€‹Î”n2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M)]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[b_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Delta_{n}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\right]
â‰²mnâ€‹Î”n2mnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹M)2]1/2\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{2}}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]^{1/2}
â‰¤mnâ€‹Î”n2mnâ€‹Î”n3/2â€‹(âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹M)2])1/2â†’ğ‘ƒ0,\displaystyle\leq\frac{\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{2}}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}^{3/2}}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]\Big)^{1/2}\xrightarrow{P}0,

where we used âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹M)2]1/2â‰¤Î”nâˆ’1/2â€‹(âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹M)2])1/2\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]^{1/2}\leq\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]\Big)^{1/2}. Besides, by Cauchy-Schwarz twice, we also have

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[btiâˆ’1â€‹Î”nâ€‹x^iâ€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹(Î”iâ€‹M)]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[b_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}\hat{x}_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\right]
â‰²mnâ€‹Î”nmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[x^i2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}])1/2â€‹(âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹M)2])1/2â†’ğ‘ƒ0,\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\hat{x}_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\right]\Big)^{1/2}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]\Big)^{1/2}\xrightarrow{P}0,

Consequently, it is sufficient to prove (86) with xi=Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W+Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Jx_{i}=\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J.

Now we prove (86) when M=WM=W and we start with the case when xix_{i} is replaced with Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W. Similar to last inequality, by combining Cauchy-Schwarz and Proposition 1, we can write

mnâ€‹|âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹Î”iâ€‹M]|\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}M\right]\right|
=mnâ€‹|âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)3â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|>vn}]|\displaystyle\quad=\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{3}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}\right]\right|
â‰¤mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹W|3â€‹|xi+Îµi|]/vn\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}W|^{3}|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\right]/v_{n}
â‰¤Câ€‹mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)6]1/2â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|xi+Îµi|2]1/2/vn\displaystyle\quad\leq C\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{6}\right]^{1/2}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|^{2}\right]^{1/2}/v_{n}
â‰¤Câ€‹mnâ€‹nâ€‹Î”n3/2â€‹Î”n1/2/vnâ†’0,\displaystyle\quad\leq C\sqrt{m_{n}}n\Delta_{n}^{3/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\rightarrow 0, (87)

where the last limit follows from mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0 and Î”n1/2â‰ªvn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}.

When xix_{i} and MM are replaced with Ï‡tiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹J\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J and M=WM=W in (86), we need to show that

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹W|]â†’ğ‘ƒ0.\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}W|\right]\xrightarrow{P}0. (88)

Note that when |Î”iâ€‹W|>vn|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n} or |Îµi|>vn|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}, by HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality, and that Pâ€‹(|Îµi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) and Pâ€‹(|Î”iâ€‹W|>vn)P(|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}) decay faster than any power of Î”n\Delta_{n} since Î”n1/2/vnâ‰ªÎ”n1/2âˆ’Î²\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2-\beta}, by similar techniques as in (A.2), we obtain

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹W|â€‹(ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹W|>vn}+ğŸ{|Îµi|>vn})]=oPâ€‹(1).\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}W|\left(\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}\right)\right]=o_{P}(1). (89)

So we only focus on the case when |Î”iâ€‹W|â‰¤vn|\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n} and |Îµi|â‰¤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} with M=WM=W. Note that |xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} implies that |Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤Câ€‹vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq Cv_{n}, for some positive constant CC that we assume for simplicity is 1. In that case, for (88), it suffices to show

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹W|]â†’ğ‘ƒ0.\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}W|\right]\xrightarrow{P}0.

By HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality and Lemma 17 in [3], for any p,q>1p,q>1 such that 1/p+1/q=11/p+1/q=1,

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹W|]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}W|\right]
â‰¤mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤vn}]1/pâ€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹W|q]1/q\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}\right]^{1/p}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}W|^{q}\right]^{1/q}
â‰²mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)1/pâ€‹Î”n1/2â‰²mnâ€‹nâ€‹Î”n1/p+1/2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/p.\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})^{1/p}}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}n\Delta_{n}^{1/p+1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/p}.

So, making pp close to 1 (and qq large) and combining with (89), we get the convergence to 0 for (88) as mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0 and Î”n1/2â‰ªvn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}. Combining (A.2) and (88), we establish (86) when M=WM=W.

Next, we work on (86) with M=BM=B and we start with the case where xix_{i} is replaced with Î”iâ€‹W\Delta_{i}W. Notice that

mnâ€‹|âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹Î”iâ€‹B]|\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\right]\right|
â‰¤mnâ€‹|âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¥vn}â€‹Î”iâ€‹B]|\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\geq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\right]\right|
+mnâ€‹|âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)2â€‹Î”iâ€‹B]|.\displaystyle\qquad+\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}B\right]\right|.

For the first term, by HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality and Proposition 1, we have

mnâ€‹|âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹Ïƒtiâˆ’12â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹Î”iâ€‹B]|\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\right]\right|
â‰¤Câ€‹mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)8]1/4â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹B)4]1/4â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|xi+Îµi|2]1/2/vn\displaystyle\leq C\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{8}\right]^{1/4}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}B)^{4}\right]^{1/4}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|^{2}\right]^{1/2}/v_{n}
â‰²mnâ€‹nâ€‹Î”n3/2â€‹Î”n1/2/vn,\displaystyle\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}n\Delta_{n}^{3/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}, (90)

which vanishes under vnâ‰«Î”n1/2v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{1/2} and mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0.

For the second term, given mnâ€‹Î”nâ†’0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0, it suffices to show supiğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)2â€‹Î”iâ€‹B]=oPâ€‹(Î”n3/2)\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}B]=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). Denote Ïs=dâ€‹âŸ¨W,BâŸ©s/dâ€‹s\rho_{s}=d\langle W,B\rangle_{s}/ds. Ïs\rho_{s} is cÃ dlÃ g and bounded on the interval [tiâˆ’1,ti][t_{i-1},t_{i}]. By ItÃ´â€™s Lemma, Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, and Doobâ€™s inequality, we have

supiğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹W)2â€‹Î”iâ€‹B]â‰²Î”n3/2â€‹supiğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Ïtiâˆ’Ïtiâˆ’1)2.\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}B]\lesssim\Delta_{n}^{3/2}\sup_{i}\sqrt{\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\rho_{t_{i}}-\rho_{t_{i-1}})^{2}}.

We notice that Ï\rho is right-continuous and uniformly bounded on [0,1][0,1] and thus, ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹(Ïtiâˆ’Ïtiâˆ’1)2â†’0\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\rho_{t_{i}}-\rho_{t_{i-1}})^{2}\rightarrow 0 Next, we check the case where xix_{i} and MM are replaced with Î”iâ€‹J\Delta_{i}J and BB in (86), respectively. Similar to (88), we need to show that

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹B|]â†’ğ‘ƒ0.\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\right]\xrightarrow{P}0. (91)

Following the similar technique as in (88) and (A.2), note that when |Î”iâ€‹W|>vn|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n} or |Îµi|>vn|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}, by HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality, and that Pâ€‹(|Îµi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) and Pâ€‹(|Î”iâ€‹W|>vn)P(|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}) decay faster than any power of Î”n\Delta_{n} due to Î”n1/2/vnâ‰ªÎ”n1/2âˆ’Î²\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2-\beta}, we obtain

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹ğŸ{|xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹B|â€‹(ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹W|>vn}+ğŸ{|Îµi|>vn})]=oPâ€‹(1).\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\left(\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}\right)\right]=o_{P}(1).

So, when |Î”iâ€‹W|â‰¤vn|\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n} and |Îµi|â‰¤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}, note |xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} implies that |Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤Câ€‹vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq Cv_{n}, for some positive constant CC. Then, for (91), it suffices to show

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹B|]â†’ğ‘ƒ0.\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\right]\xrightarrow{P}0.

By HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality and Lemma 17 in [3], for any p,q>1p,q>1 such that 1/p+1/q=11/p+1/q=1,

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹B|]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\right]
â‰¤mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[(Î”iâ€‹J)2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤vn}]1/pâ€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹B|q]1/q\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}\right]^{1/p}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}B|^{q}\right]^{1/q}
â‰²mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(Î”nâ€‹vn2â€‹pâˆ’Y)1/pâ€‹Î”n1/2â‰²mnâ€‹nâ€‹Î”n1/p+1/2â€‹vn2âˆ’Y/p.\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})^{{1/p}}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}n\Delta_{n}^{1/p+1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/p}.

So, again, making pp close to 1 (and qq large), we get the convergence to 0, establishing (86) with M=BM=B.

Lastly, we want to show (86) for any bounded martingale MM which is orthogonal to WW. We first consider the case when xix_{i} is replaced with Î”iâ€‹J\Delta_{i}J. As before, we can deal with the cases |Î”iâ€‹W|>vn|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n} or Îµi>vn\varepsilon_{i}>v_{n}, since Pâ€‹(|Îµi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) and Pâ€‹(|Î”iâ€‹W|>vn)P(|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}) decays fast. So, we assume that |Î”iâ€‹W|â‰¤vn|\Delta_{i}W|\leq{v_{n}} and |Îµi|â‰¤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq{v_{n}}, so that, together with |xi+Îµi|â‰¤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}, we have |Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤3â€‹vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}. Then, we proceed as follows:

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹J|2â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤3â€‹vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹M|]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}M|\right]
â‰¤mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹J|4â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤3â€‹vn}]1/2â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹M|2]1/2\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{4}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}\right]^{1/2}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]^{1/2}
â‰¤mnâ€‹(âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹J|4â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤3â€‹vn}])1/2â€‹(âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹M|2])1/2\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{4}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}\right]\right)^{1/2}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]\right)^{1/2}
â‰²mnâ€‹(nâ€‹Î”nâ€‹vn4âˆ’Y)1/2â€‹(1mn1/2â€‹Î”n1/2)=(Î”nâˆ’1â€‹vn4âˆ’Y)1/2â‰ª1,\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}(n\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})^{1/2}\Big(\frac{1}{m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}}\Big)=(\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y})^{1/2}\ll 1,

which follows from vnâ‰ªÎ”n1/(4âˆ’Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}. For the cross-product Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹Wâ€‹Î”iâ€‹J\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W\Delta_{i}J, when expanding xi2x_{i}^{2}, and again assuming |Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤3â€‹vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}, we have, for any p>1p>1:

mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹J|â€‹|Î”iâ€‹W|â€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤3â€‹vn}â€‹|Î”iâ€‹M|]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J||\Delta_{i}W|\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}M|\right]
â‰¤mnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹J|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤3â€‹vn}]12â€‹pâ€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹W|2â€‹ppâˆ’1]pâˆ’12â€‹pâ€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹M|2]12\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}\right]^{\frac{1}{2p}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}W|^{\frac{2p}{p-1}}\right]^{\frac{p-1}{2p}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}
â‰¤mnâ€‹Î”n1/2â€‹(âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹(ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹J|2â€‹pâ€‹ğŸ{|Î”iâ€‹J|â‰¤3â€‹vn}])1/p)1/2\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}\right]\big)^{1/p}\right)^{1/2}
Ã—(âˆ‘i=1nKmnâ€‹Î”nâ€‹(tiâˆ’1âˆ’Ï„)â€‹ğ”¼iâˆ’1â€‹[|Î”iâ€‹M|2])1/2\displaystyle\qquad\times\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]\right)^{1/2}
â‰²mn1/2â€‹Î”n1/2â€‹(nâ€‹Î”n1/pâ€‹vn2âˆ’Y/p)1/2â€‹(1mn1/2â€‹Î”n1/2).\displaystyle\quad\lesssim m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}(n\Delta_{n}^{1/p}v_{n}^{2-Y/p})^{1/2}\Big(\frac{1}{m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}}\Big).

By taking pp close to 1, the above vanishes given vnâ†’0v_{n}\rightarrow 0. Finally, we consider the case when xix_{i} is replaced with Ïƒtiâˆ’1â€‹Î”iâ€‹W\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W. Note that

(Î”iâ€‹W)2=2â€‹âˆ«tiâˆ’1ti(Wsâˆ’Wtiâˆ’1)â€‹ğ‘‘Ws+Î”n,(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}=2\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}(W_{s}-W_{t_{i-1}})dW_{s}+\Delta_{n},

and since MM is orthogonal to WW,
